PREFACE
This code of the Village of Wadsworth, as supplemented, contains ordinances up
to and including ordinance 2024-1166, passed December 17, 2024. Ordinances of
the Village adopted after said ordinance supersede the provisions of this code
to the extent that they are in conflict or inconsistent therewith. Consult the
Village office in order to ascertain whether any particular provision of the
code has been amended, superseded or repealed.
American Legal Publishing
Cincinnati, Ohio

Listed ordinances have been passed, but they have not been incorporated into
the code and they may not show the original ordinances in their entirety.
Please contact the office of the clerk if there are any questions concerning
the ordinances listed.
 
 
ADOPTING ORDINANCE
AN ORDINANCE ADOPTING THE VILLAGE CODE OF WADSWORTH, ILLINOIS
96-462
   BE IT ORDAINED by the President and Board of Trustees of the Village of
Wadsworth, Lake County, Illinois, as follows:
   SECTION I: This Village Code is hereby adopted and declared to be and shall
hereafter constitute the official Village Code of Wadsworth. This Village Code
of Ordinances shall be known and cited as the WADSWORTH VILLAGE CODE and it is
hereby published by authority of the Board of Trustees and shall be kept up to
date by the Village Clerk under the direction of the Village Attorney, acting
for said Village Board of Trustees.
   SECTION II: There is hereby adopted, as a method of perpetual codification,
the loose-leaf type of binding together with the continuous supplement service,
whereby each newly adopted ordinance of a general and permanent nature
amending, altering, adding or deleting provisions of the Official Village Code
is identified by the proper catchline and is inserted in the proper place in
each of the official copies, one copy of which shall be maintained in the
office of the Village Clerk and be available for inspection at any and all
times that said office is regularly open.
   SECTION III: All ordinances of a general nature included in this Official
Village Code shall be considered as a continuation of said ordinance provision
and the fact that some provisions have been deliberately eliminated by the
governing body shall not serve to cause any interruption in the continuous
effectiveness of ordinances included in said Official Village Code. All
ordinances of a special nature, such as tax levy ordinances, bond ordinances,
franchises, vacating ordinances and annexation ordinances shall continue in
full force and effect unless specifically repealed or amended by a provision of
the Village Code. Such ordinances are not intended to be included in the
Official Village Code.
   SECTION IV: It shall be unlawful for any person, firm or corporation to
change or amend by additions or deletions, any part or portion of such Code, or
to insert or delete pages or portions thereof, or to alter or tamper with such
Code in any manner whatsoever which will cause the law of the Village to be
misrepresented thereby.
   SECTION V: All ordinances or parts of ordinances in conflict herewith are
hereby expressly repealed to the extent, and only to the extent, they are in
conflict herewith.
   SECTION VI: This Ordinance shall be in full force and effect from and after
its passage, approval, and publication, as provided by law.
   Passed by the Corporate Authorities on December 3, 1996, on a roll call vote
as follows:

CHAPTER 1
OFFICIAL MUNICIPAL CODE
SECTION:
1-1-1: Title
1-1-2: Acceptance
1-1-3: Code Alterations
1-1-1: TITLE:
Upon adoption by the Board of Trustees, this Village Code is hereby declared to
be and shall hereafter constitute the official Village Code of Wadsworth. This
Village Code of ordinances shall be known and cited as WADSWORTH VILLAGE CODE,
and it is hereby published by authority of the Board of Trustees and shall be
kept up to date as ordinances are adopted, under the direction of the Village
legal counsel, acting for said Village Board of Trustees. Any reference to the
number of any section contained herein shall be understood to refer to the
position of the same number, its appropriate chapter and title heading, and to
the general penalty clause relating thereto, as well as to the section itself,
when reference is made to this Village Code by title in any legal document.
(1996 Code)
1-1-2: ACCEPTANCE:
This Village Code, as hereby presented in printed form, shall hereafter be
received without further proof in all courts and in all administrative
tribunals of this State as the ordinances of the Village of a general and
permanent effect, except certain excluded ordinances of a special nature. (1996
Code)
1-1-3: CODE ALTERATIONS:
It shall be deemed unlawful for any person to alter, change, replace or deface
in any way any section or any page of this Village Code in such a manner that
the meaning of any phrase or order may be changed or omitted. Replacement pages
may be inserted according to the official instructions when so authorized by
the Village Board. The Village Clerk shall see that the replacement pages are
properly inserted in the official copies maintained in the office of the Clerk.
Any person having in his custody an official copy of this Village Code shall
make every effort to maintain this Code in an up-to-date and efficient manner.
He shall see to the immediate insertion of new or replacement pages when such
are delivered to him or made available to him through the office of the Village
Clerk. Said Code books, while in actual possession of officials and other
interested persons, shall be and remain the property of the Village and shall
be returned to the office of the Clerk when directed so to do by order of the
Village Board. (1996 Code)
CHAPTER 2
SAVING CLAUSE
SECTION:
1-2-1: Court Proceedings
1-2-2: Severability Clause
1-2-1: COURT PROCEEDINGS:
   A.   No new ordinance shall be construed or held to repeal a former
ordinance whether such former ordinance is expressly repealed or not, as to any
offense committed against such former ordinance or as to any act done, any
penalty, forfeiture or punishment so incurred, or any right accrued or claim
arising under the former ordinance, or in any way whatever to affect any such
offense or act so committed or so done, or any penalty, forfeiture or
punishment so incurred or any right accrued or claim arising before the new
ordinance takes effect, save only that the proceedings thereafter shall conform
to the ordinance in force at the time of such proceeding, so far as
practicable. If any penalty, forfeiture or punishment be mitigated by any
provision of a new ordinance, such provision may be, by consent of the party
affected, applied to any judgment announced after the new ordinance takes
effect.
   B.   This Section shall extend to all repeals, either by express words or
implication, whether the repeal is in the ordinance making any new provisions
upon the same subject or in any other ordinance.
   C.   Nothing contained in this Chapter shall be construed as abating any
action now pending under or by virtue of any general ordinance of the Village
herein repealed and the provisions of all general ordinances contained in this
Code shall be deemed to be continuing provisions and not a new enactment of the
same provision; nor shall this Chapter be deemed as discontinuing, abating,
modifying or altering any penalty accrued or to accrue, or as affecting the
liability of any person, firm or corporation or as waiving any right of the
Village under any ordinance or provision thereof in force at the time of the
adoption of this Village Code. (1996 Code)
1-2-2: SEVERABILITY CLAUSE:
If any section, subsection, subdivision, paragraph, sentence, clause or phrase
of this Village Code or any part thereof is for any reason held to be
unconstitutional or invalid or ineffective by any court of competent
jurisdiction, such decision shall not affect the validity or effectiveness of
the remaining portions of this Code, or any part thereof. The Village Board of
Trustees hereby declares that it would have passed each section, subsection,
subdivision, paragraph, sentence, clause or phrase thereof irrespective of the
fact that any one or more sections, subsections, subdivisions, paragraphs,
sentences, clauses or phrases be declared unconstitutional, invalid or
ineffective. (1996 Code)
CHAPTER 3
DEFINITIONS
SECTION:
1-3-1: Construction Of Words
1-3-2: Definitions, General
1-3-3: Catchlines
1-3-1: CONSTRUCTION OF WORDS:
   A.   Whenever any word in any section of this Village Code importing the
plural number is used in describing or referring to any matters, parties or
persons, any single matter, party or person shall be deemed to be included,
although distributive words may not have been used. When any subject matter,
party or person is referred to in this Village Code by words importing the
singular number only, or a particular gender, several matters, parties or
persons and the opposite gender and bodies corporate shall be deemed to be
included; provided, that these rules of construction shall not be applied to
any section of this Village Code which contains any express provision excluding
such construction or where the subject matter or context may be repugnant
thereto.
   B.   The word "ordinance" contained in the ordinances of the Village has
been changed in the content of this Village Code to "Title", "Chapter",
"Section" and/or "subsection" or words of like import for organizational and
clarification purposes only. Such change to the Village's ordinances is not
meant to amend passage and effective dates of such original ordinances. (1996
Code)
1-3-2: DEFINITIONS, GENERAL:
Whenever the following words or terms are used in this Code, they shall have
such meanings herein ascribed to them, unless the context makes such meaning
repugnant thereto:
AGENT: A person acting on behalf of another with authority conferred, either
expressly or by implication.
BOARD: Unless otherwise indicated, the Board of Trustees of the Village of
Wadsworth.
CLERK: The Village Clerk of the Village of Wadsworth, Illinois.
CODE: The Municipal Code of Wadsworth, Illinois, and amendments thereto.
COUNTY: The County of Lake, State of Illinois.
EMPLOYEES: Whenever reference is made in this Code to a Village employee by
title only, this shall be construed as though followed by the words, "of the
Village of Wadsworth".
FEE: A sum of money charged by the Village for the carrying on of a business,
profession or occupation or for services performed by or costs incurred by, or
otherwise established, by the Village Board.
FISCAL YEAR: The fiscal year of the Village is hereby established as commencing
on May 1 of each year and ending on April 30 of the following year.
GENDER: A word importing either the masculine or feminine gender only shall
extend and be applied to the other gender and to persons.
LICENSE: The permission granted for the carrying on of a business, profession
or occupation.
MISDEMEANOR: Any offense for which a sentence to a term of imprisonment in
other than a penitentiary for less than one year may be imposed.
NUISANCE 1 : Anything offensive to the sensibilities of reasonable persons, or
any act or activity creating a hazard which threatens the health and welfare of
inhabitants of the village, or any activity which by its perpetuation can
reasonably be said to have a detrimental effect on the property of a person or
persons within the community.
OCCUPANT: As applied to a building or land, shall include any person who
occupies the whole or any part of such building or land whether alone or with
others.
OFFENSE: Any act forbidden by any provision of this code or the omission of any
act required by the provisions of this code.
OFFICERS: Whenever reference is made in this code to a village officer by title
only, this shall be construed as though followed by the words "of the village
of Wadsworth".
OPERATOR: The person who is in charge of any operation, business or profession.
OWNER: As applied to a building or land, shall include any part owner, joint
owner, or tenant in common.
PERSON: Any partnership, corporation, association, individual, or any other
legal entity.
PERSONAL PROPERTY: Includes every description of money, goods, chattels,
effects, evidence of rights in action and all written instruments by which any
pecuniary obligation, right or title to property is created, acknowledged,
transferred, increased, defeated, discharged or diminished and every right or
interest therein.
RETAILER: Unless otherwise specifically defined, shall be understood to relate
to the sale of goods, merchandise, articles or things in small quantities
directly to the consumer.
RIGHT OF WAY: A public street for public travel including the entire dedicated
width of the street, which includes the shoulders and ditches.
SHALL: The word "shall" is mandatory and not discretionary.
STATE: The state of Illinois.
STREET: Shall include alleys, lanes, courts, boulevards, public ways, public
squares, public places and sidewalks.
TENANT: As applied to a building or land, shall include any person who occupies
the whole or any part of such buildings or land, whether alone or with others.
VILLAGE: The village of Wadsworth, county of Lake, state of Illinois.
WHOLESALER AND WHOLESALE DEALER: Unless otherwise specifically defined, such
terms shall be understood to relate to the sale of goods, merchandise, articles
or things in quantity to persons who purchase for the purpose of resale.
WRITTEN, IN WRITING: May include printing and any other mode of representing
words and letters, but when the written signature of any person is required by
law to any official or public writing or bond, it shall be in the proper
handwriting of such person, or in case such person is unable to write, by such
person's proper mark. (1996 Code; amd. Ord. 2008-754, 6-3-2008)
 
Notes
1 1. Also see definition contained in section
  4-1-1 of this code.
1-3-3: CATCHLINES:
The catchlines of the several sections of this code are intended as mere
catchwords to indicate the content of the section and shall not be deemed or
taken to be titles of such sections, nor be deemed to govern, limit, modify or
in any manner affect the scope, meaning or intent of the provisions of any
division or section hereof, nor unless expressly so provided, shall they be so
deemed when any of such sections, including the catchlines, are amended or
reenacted. (1996 Code)
CHAPTER 4
GENERAL PENALTY
SECTION:
1-4-1: General Penalty
1-4-2: Liability Of Officers
1-4-1: GENERAL PENALTY:
For all provisions of this code that are not referenced in the table of section
1-13-7 of this title, any person convicted of a violation of any provision of
this code shall be fined not less than one hundred dollars ($100.00) nor more
than seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00) for each offense 1 , and a separate
offense shall be deemed committed for each day a violation occurs or continues.
(Ord. 2008-752, 2-5-2008)
 
Notes
1 1. 65 ILCS 5/1-2-1.
1-4-2: LIABILITY OF OFFICERS:
No provision of this code designating the duties of any officer or employee
shall be so construed as to make such officer or employee liable for any fine
or penalty provided for a failure to perform such duty, unless the intention of
the board of trustees to impose such fine or penalty on such officer or
employee is specifically and clearly expressed in the section creating the
duty. (1996 Code)
CHAPTER 5
PRESIDENT AND BOARD OF TRUSTEES
SECTION:
1-5-1: Meetings
1-5-2: Presiding Officer
1-5-3: Ordinances
1-5-4: The Journal
1-5-5: Adoption Of Robert's Rules Of Order Revised
1-5-6: Reserved
1-5-7: Commencement Of Terms
1-5-1: MEETINGS:
   A.   Regular Meetings: The regular meetings of the board of trustees shall
be held on the first and third Tuesday of each month of the year at six o'clock
(6:00) P.M. at the Wadsworth Village Hall, 14155 West Wadsworth Road,
Wadsworth, Illinois, or such other location as may be designated from time to
time by the village board. The duration of said meetings shall not exceed two
(2) hours, but may be extended following approval by the village board. (Ord.
2013-889, 2-5-2013)
   B.   Special Meetings: Special meetings of the village board may be called
by the president, or by any three (3) trustees in accordance with the
provisions of the open meetings act. Notice shall be given to each board member
as soon as possible. (Ord. 2011-840, 4-19-2011)
   C.   Quorum: If no quorum be present, the board of trustees members present
shall adjourn or recess the board by a majority vote to another day. (Ord. 11,
1-14-1963; amd. 1996 Code)
   D.   Public Comment: The public shall be permitted to comment at all regular
village board meetings in accordance with the open meetings act, under such
rules as may be determined from time to time by the village board. (Ord. 2011-
840, 4-19-2011)
1-5-2: PRESIDING OFFICER:
   A.   President: The president shall preside at all meetings of the board of
trustees.
   B.   President Pro Tem: The board of trustees shall elect one of its number
president pro tem of the board who shall act as presiding officer of the board
during a temporary absence or disability of the president, or when requested so
to do by the president. The president pro tem of the board, when acting as
presiding officer, shall vote on all questions on which the vote is taken by
"ayes" and "nays", the president pro tem's name being called last.
   C.   Temporary Chairman: Each meeting of the board of trustees shall convene
at the time appointed for such meeting, as provided by ordinance. In the
absence of the president and president pro tem, a temporary chairman for the
meeting shall be elected by a majority vote of the trustees present from among
their members. The clerk, or someone appointed to fill the clerk's place by the
presiding officer, shall thereupon immediately call the roll of members. (Ord.
11, 1-14-1963; amd. 1996 Code)
1-5-3: ORDINANCES:
   A.   Style Of Ordinances: The style of all ordinances shall be: "BE IT
ORDAINED BY THE PRESIDENT AND BOARD OF TRUSTEES OF THE VILLAGE OF WADSWORTH" as
is provided by statute.
   B.   Aye And Nay Vote: The ayes and nays shall be taken upon the passage of
all ordinances and on all propositions to create any liability against the
village, or for the expenditure or appropriation of its money, and in all other
cases at the request of any member of the board; and such vote shall be entered
on the journal of the proceedings, as is provided by statute.
   C.   Record Of Ordinances: The clerk shall keep a record of all ordinances
passed in an ordinance book for such purpose. (Ord. 11, 1-14-1963; amd. 1996
Code)
1-5-4: THE JOURNAL:
The clerk shall keep the journal and minutes of the proceedings of the village
board of trustees, in accordance with 65 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/3.1-35-
90. (Ord. 2009-785, 5-19-2009)
1-5-5: ADOPTION OF ROBERT'S RULES OF ORDER REVISED:
The rules of parliamentary practice comprised in the latest published edition
of "Robert's Rules Of Order Revised" shall govern the board in all cases to
which they are applicable and in which they are not inconsistent with the
special rules of this board. (Ord. 11, 1-14-1963)
1-5-6: RESERVED:
(Ord. 2010-805, 1-5-2010)
1-5-7: COMMENCEMENT OF TERMS:
The terms of elected officers in the village of Wadsworth are hereby declared
to commence upon inauguration of the officers. Inauguration of the officers
shall occur at the first regular meeting of the village board of trustees in
the month of May following receipt of the official election results from the
county clerk of the regular municipal election at which the officers were
elected. (Ord. 2009-784, 5-19-2009)
CHAPTER 6
VILLAGE OFFICERS AND EMPLOYEES
SECTION:
1-6-1: Compensation Of Officers
1-6-2: Employees
1-6-3: Administrative Assistant
1-6-4: Code Compliance Officer
1-6-5: Village Administrator
1-6-6: Village Clerk
1-6-7: Deputy Village Clerk
1-6-8: Treasurer
1-6-9: Village Attorney
1-6-1: COMPENSATION OF OFFICERS:
   A.   Village President, Village Clerk, Trustees: The Village President,
Village Clerk and Village Trustees shall receive the following compensation:
 
1. Village President $1,000.00 per month
2. Village Clerk     600.00 per month
3. Village Trustees  525.00 per month
 
Effective May 1, 2025, the Village President and Village Trustees shall receive
the following compensation:
 
1. Village President $1,100.00 per month
2. Village Trustees  625.00 per month
 
Provided, however, any increase in compensation from that established by
Ordinance 2024-1161 shall not be payable to the Village Trustees whose current
terms of office commenced prior to May 1, 2025, but rather during their
respective current terms, they shall be paid five hundred twenty five dollars
($525.00) per month in accordance with the compensation set forth in Ordinance
2019-1057. At such time as such Village Trustee commences a new term of office,
such Village Trustee shall then be paid six hundred twenty five dollars
($625.00) per month in accordance with the terms of this section and shall no
longer be compensated as set forth in Ordinance 2019-1057. (Ord. 2018-1048, 10-
2-2018; amd. Ord. 2024-1161, 10-15-2024)
B.   Village Clerk: Effective May 1, 2019, the Village Clerk shall be paid such
salary as the Village Board may establish from time to time. (Ord. 2019-1057,
4-16-2019)
C.   Village Treasurer: The Village Treasurer shall be paid such salary as the
Village Board may establish from time to time.
D.   Waiver Of Compensation: An elected Village official (Village President/
Village Trustee(s)) shall retain the prerogative to waive compensation by
written notification to the Village Clerk. (Ord. 2018-1048, 10-2-2018)
1-6-2: EMPLOYEES:
Village employees shall be subject to the Personnel Policy Manual adopted by
the Village Board, as such policy may be amended from time to time. (Ord. 2013-
894, 5-21-2013)
1-6-3: ADMINISTRATIVE ASSISTANT:
   A.   Employment: The Administrative Assistant shall be a full time employee
of the Village.
   B.   Duties Generally: It shall be the duty of the Administrative Assistant
to supervise all Village employees, the operation of the Village Hall, the
administration of escrow of funds for professional fees as set forth in section
1-7-1 of this title and to administrate all policies set forth by the Village
Board. (1996 Code)
1-6-4: CODE COMPLIANCE OFFICER:
   A.   Established: The office of code compliance officer is hereby
established.
   B.   Appointment: The code compliance officer shall be appointed by the
village president with the concurrence of the village board and shall serve at
the pleasure of the village president and village board of trustees.
   C.   Powers And Duties: The code compliance officer shall have the power to
investigate ordinance compliance within the village, serve and post notices of
ordinance violations and take action to secure ordinance compliance, including
recommending to the village attorney that court proceedings be initiated to
secure ordinance enforcement and penalties for violation of village ordinances.
(Ord. 250, 2-22-1988; amd. 1996 Code)
1-6-5: VILLAGE ADMINISTRATOR:
The village administrator shall be an employee and not an officer of the
village.
   A.   The village administrator shall be selected by a two- thirds (2/3) vote
of the village trustees. The terms of his employment shall be set forth in a
written employment contract the term of which shall not exceed the term of the
village president holding office when the contract is executed. The written
contract shall establish salary, duties, benefits, and other particulars of the
employment.
   B.   No member of the corporate authorities shall serve as village
administrator during his term of office or within two (2) years after the
expiration of that term.
   C.   The village administrator is encouraged to but need not be a resident
of Wadsworth.
   D.   The duties of the village administrator shall include:
      1.   The village administrator shall be responsible to the corporate
authorities and shall be responsible for the proper administration of the day
to day activities of the village.
      2.   The village administrator shall be responsible to implement the
policies established by the village board.
      3.   The village administrator shall coordinate and supervise the work of
all village employees, who shall be subordinate to him, but the village
administrator shall not be responsible for the hiring or termination of village
employees.
      4.   The village administrator shall attend all village board meetings.
The village administrator shall also attend the plan commission's, and zoning
board of appeals' meetings when necessary or advisable. The village
administrator shall have the privilege of taking part in the discussion of all
matters coming before the board, the plan commission and zoning board of
appeals.
      5.   The village administrator shall be responsible for preparing the
agenda for all regular and special meetings of the board. The agenda and
supporting material shall be delivered to the president and each board member
two (2) days preceding each regular meeting.
      6.   The village administrator shall be responsible to the president and
board of trustees of the village for the proper administration of all the
affairs and ordinances of the village and provide for the enforcement of all
village ordinances.
      7.   The village administrator shall serve as budget officer and annually
prepare and submit to the village board by the date set by the village board a
recommended budget.
      8.   The village administrator shall prepare and submit to the village
board within sixty (60) days subsequent to the end of the fiscal year a
complete report on the finances and the administrative activities of the
village for that fiscal year.
      9.   The village administrator shall make such other reports to the
village board as the village board may require from time to time concerning the
operations of the village.
      10.   The village administrator shall keep the board informed on the
conditions and needs of the village and recommend to the board adoption of any
such measures he may deem necessary or expedient in the operation of the
village.
      11.   The village administrator shall advise the village board on pending
decisions of public policy and make recommendations he deems necessary or
expedient for the health, safety, or welfare of the village or its employees.
      12.   The village administrator shall purchase all materials, supplies,
and equipment authorized by the board and for which funds are provided in the
annual appropriation ordinance.
      13.   The village administrator shall annually prepare and submit an
employee review of all employees to the village board by the date set by the
village board.
      14.   The village administrator shall provide staff support services for
the village president and trustees.
      15.   The village administrator shall keep a current inventory of all
real and personal property of the village and the location of such property.
      16.   The village administrator shall be responsible for the care and
custody of all records of the village except as otherwise required by law.
      17.   The village administrator shall investigate all complaints
concerning the administration of the village.
      18.   The village administrator shall monitor to ensure that all
franchises, permits, and privileges granted by the village are faithfully
observed.
      19.   The village administrator shall perform such other duties as
specified by village ordinance, as may be required from time to time by the
village board, and those other duties set forth in the employment contract.
   E.   The village administrator shall be subject to removal by the village
board by a two-thirds (2/3) vote of the trustees.
   F.   The village administrator shall devote his full time to the performance
of his duties and not engage in any other employment without consent of the
board.
   G.   The village administrator shall be subject to the authority and
direction of the village board.
   H.   The village administrator shall furnish a surety bond in the amount of
fifty thousand dollars ($50,000.00) to be approved by the village board. The
premium for the bond shall be paid by the village.
   I.   Elected officials shall deal with village employees through the village
administrator. Elected officials shall not give orders to any subordinate
employees of the village administrator. (Ord. 2000-550, 6-6-2000)
   J.   The village administrator is authorized to make expenditures that are
specifically authorized by the village board, as well as expenditures for
routine day to day operating and maintenance activities without specific
approval by the village board but only in accordance with the following
policies:
      1.   The administrator is authorized to execute contracts and make
expenditures that have been specifically authorized by the village board.
      2.   The administrator is authorized to execute contracts and make
expenditures for routine operating and maintenance activities that cannot wait
until the next regularly scheduled village board meeting in an amount not to
exceed five thousand dollars ($5,000.00). The funds must be on hand to pay for
the resulting costs and authorization is subject to the prior verbal approval
of the mayor and senior trustee, or in their absence, at least two (2) other
trustees. Any such expenditure is subject to ratification by the village board
to confirm that it was made in accordance with this section. Examples of
routine operating and maintenance activities include utility bills, janitorial
services, and similar expenditures that occur on a regular basis.
      3.   The administrator is authorized to execute contracts and make
expenditures up to and including fifteen thousand dollars ($15,000.00) for
urgent repairs to Village infrastructure or equipment that cannot wait until
the next regularly scheduled village board meeting. The funds must be on hand
to pay for the resulting costs and authorization is subject to the prior verbal
approval of two trustees who sit on the Board's Road and Bridge Committee, one
of whom must be the Committee's Chair. Any such expenditure is subject to
ratification by the village board to confirm that it was made in accordance
with this section.
      4.   The administrator is authorized to execute contracts and make
expenditures up to and including twenty thousand dollars ($20,000.00) for an
emergency situation that poses an imminent danger to the health, safety, and
welfare of the village that cannot wait forty eight (48) hours to schedule and
convene a special village board meeting. The funds must be on hand to pay for
the resulting costs and authorization is subject to the prior verbal approval
of the mayor and senior trustee, or in their absence, at least two (2) other
trustees. Any such expenditure is subject to ratification by the village board
to confirm that they were made in accordance with this section. In the event
any emergency expenditure would exceed twenty thousand dollars ($20,000.00),
the village administrator must notify the village president that a special
meeting must be called to authorize the expenditure.
      5.   For any expenditure in excess of five thousand dollars ($5,000.00),
the village administrator must obtain at least three (3) written quotes for the
expenditures except for emergency situations. (Ord. 2000-550, 6-6-2000; amd.
Ord. 2013-911, 11-5-2013; Ord. 2020-1087, 6-16-2020)
1-6-6: VILLAGE CLERK:
The Office of Village Clerk is hereby established. Beginning on May 1, 2019,
the Village Clerk shall be appointed by the Village President with the advice
and consent of the Village Board of Trustees. Beginning on May 1, 2019, the
Village Clerk shall perform all duties pursuant to 65 Illinois Compiled
Statutes 5/3.1-35-90. Beginning on May 1, 2019, the Village Clerk need not be a
resident of the Village of Wadsworth. The Village Clerk shall serve for a term
of one year, expiring at the first regular meeting of the Village Board of
Trustees in May of the following year, or until their successor is appointed
and qualified. (Ord. 2019-1058, 5-7-2019)
1-6-7: DEPUTY VILLAGE CLERK:
There is hereby created the position of Deputy Village Clerk. The Deputy
Village Clerk shall be appointed by and be under the direct supervision and
control of the Village Clerk. The Deputy Village Clerk shall perform all duties
prescribed by the Village Clerk pursuant to 65 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/
3.1-35-95. The salary, if any, of the Deputy Village Clerk shall be as from
time to time established by the Village Board of Trustees. The Deputy Village
Clerk may be terminated at any time by the Village Clerk or the Village Board
of Trustees. The Deputy Village Clerk need not be a resident of the Village of
Wadsworth. (Ord. 2018-1051, 10-16-2018)
1-6-8: TREASURER:
There is hereby created the Office of Village Treasurer. The Village Treasurer
shall be appointed by the Village President with the advice and consent of the
Village Board of Trustees. The Village Treasurer shall perform all duties
pursuant to 65 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/3.1-35-40 thru 65 Illinois Compiled
Statutes 5/3.1-35-85. The Village Treasurer need not be a resident of the
Village of Wadsworth. (Ord. 2018-1051, 10-16-2018)
1-6-9: VILLAGE ATTORNEY:
The Office of Village Attorney is hereby established. The Village Attorney
shall be appointed by the Village President with the advice and consent of the
Village Board of Trustees. The Village Attorney shall have the status of an
independent contractor. (Ord. 2018-1051, 10-16-2018)
CHAPTER 7
MUNICIPAL EXPENSES AND CERTAIN FEES
SECTION:
1-7-1: Responsibility
1-7-2: Professional Escrow
1-7-3: Administrative Assistant, Duties
1-7-4: Estimated Costs; Deposit
1-7-5: Account
1-7-6: Notification Of Professionals; Billing
1-7-7: Disbursements
1-7-8: Replenishment
1-7-9: Bill Directly
1-7-10: Final Disbursement
1-7-11: Copies Of Documents
1-7-1: RESPONSIBILITY:
Any person seeking the village's approval or consideration of any matter shall
be responsible for any professional fees incurred by the village in reviewing
the requested action or matter and in acting upon the requested approval or
consideration, including, but not limited to, engineering fees, planner fees
and attorney fees incurred by the village. This obligation remains in effect
notwithstanding that the professional escrow fund has not been established, is
insufficient or has been depleted. (Ord. 2001-573, 3-6-2001)
1-7-2: PROFESSIONAL ESCROW:
Any person requesting consideration or action by the village shall be required
whenever practicable to deposit sufficient funds necessary to defray
anticipated professional costs to be incurred by the village. (Ord. 2001-573,
3-6-2001)
1-7-3: ADMINISTRATIVE ASSISTANT, DUTIES:
The administrative assistant or such other person as may be designated from
time to time by the village board shall be responsible for the administration
of escrow of funds for professional fees. (Ord. 2001-573, 3-6-2001)
1-7-4: ESTIMATED COSTS; DEPOSIT:
The administrative assistant shall, upon receipt of a matter which may or will
require professional services to be rendered to the village, whenever
practicable make an estimate of the amount of the cost of expected services
based on the nature of the matter, its complexity, the relative need for
professional advice and the expected duration of processing the matter. The
administrative assistant shall so notify the individual applicant in writing:
   A.   With the estimate of the necessary funds to defray all professional
costs the village might incur in the course of reviewing the matter submitted
by the applicant or other individual. The estimate shall be derived from the
approved fee schedule in effect from time to time or when necessary by
consultation with the professionals who are expected to render services
regarding the matter.
   B.   And advise the individual that the application or matter shall not
thereafter be reviewed or acted upon by the village unless and until said sum
is received by the administrative assistant. (Ord. 2001-573, 3-6-2001)
1-7-5: ACCOUNT:
Upon receipt of said sum, the administrative assistant shall deposit the same
in a separate escrow account. (Ord. 2001-573, 3-6-2001)
1-7-6: NOTIFICATION OF PROFESSIONALS; BILLING:
Simultaneously with the sending of notice to the applicant or other individual,
the administrative assistant shall also notify the professionals whom the
village expects to utilize to review the matter. These professionals shall bill
not less frequently than monthly on said matter and otherwise keep the village
apprised of time and cost expended in providing services relating to this
matter. (Ord. 2001-573, 3-6-2001)
1-7-7: DISBURSEMENTS:
The escrow funds as deposited shall be utilized to pay for professional
expenses and any and all disbursements therefrom shall be approved by the
administrative assistant or the village board. The individual applicant who has
deposited the funds shall be periodically apprised of disbursements. (Ord.
2001-573, 3-6-2001)
1-7-8: REPLENISHMENT:
The administrative assistant shall periodically review the escrow funds on
deposit to ensure that adequate funds are available to satisfy all professional
statements relating to said matter. In the event that the administrative
assistant determines that sufficient funds are not available, the
administrative assistant shall so notify the applicant or other individual and
request a further amount to defray the anticipated additional costs in
accordance with the standards set forth above. The professionals previously
engaged shall be advised not to do any further work until said sum has been
received and the individual applicant shall be given fourteen (14) days to
deposit the additional funds. In the event that said funds are not deposited,
the village shall take no further action on the matter and shall so advise the
applicant or other individual. (Ord. 2001-573, 3-6-2001)
1-7-9: BILL DIRECTLY:
It is preferred that escrow funds are obtained whenever possible. In the event
that an escrow has not been established and funded, the responsible person
pursuant to section
1-7-1 of this chapter may be billed directly by the village. (Ord. 2001-573, 3-
6-2001)
1-7-10: FINAL DISBURSEMENT:
At the conclusion of the matter and after all outstanding professional fees
incurred by the village in review of the matter have been satisfied in full,
the administrative assistant shall remit the balance, if any, to the person who
had deposited the funds. (Ord. 2001-573, 3-6-2001)
1-7-11: COPIES OF DOCUMENTS:
A fee for providing copies of documents to the public is hereby established as
follows:
 
1 to 4 pages               $0.25 per page
5 pages and above          0.15 per page in excess of 4 pages
Certification of documents 1.50 per document to be certified by the clerk
 
(Ord. 2001-573, 3-6-2001)
CHAPTER 8
INDEMNITY AND LEGAL ASSISTANCE
SECTION:
1-8-1: Purpose
1-8-2: Application
1-8-3: Legal Assistance
1-8-4: Indemnification
1-8-5: Applicability Of Chapter
1-8-1: PURPOSE:
The purpose of this Chapter is to indemnify and hold harmless Village
officials, officers, employees and agents acting on behalf of the Village from
any claims or causes of action that arise as a result of the performance of
their duties. (1996 Code)
1-8-2: APPLICATION:
The provisions of this Chapter shall apply to and be for the benefit of all
elected or appointed officers and officials, employees, and agents, including,
but not limited to the Village Engineer, Village Planner and Village Attorney
of the Village. (1996 Code)
1-8-3: LEGAL ASSISTANCE:
The Village may, at the request of an officer, employee or agents, or former
officer, employee or agent, appoint counsel to appear and defend him and pay
costs or shall reimburse said officer, employee or agent for reasonable
attorney's fees and costs expended by him, upon the following conditions:
   A.   Claim Or Action Against Officer Or Employee: If any claim or action or
investigation, either civil or criminal in nature, is instituted against an
officer, employee or agent, or former officer, employee or agent, of the
Village where such claim or action arises out of:
      1.   An act or omission made in good faith occurring within the scope of
his employment and respective duties as elected or appointed official, employee
or agent of the Village.
      2.   An investigation by any Federal, state or municipality, or agency
thereof, involving the officer, employee or agent of the Village in nature of
his duties or actions as such officer, employee or agent of the Village.
      3.   An investigation of any officer, employee or agent of the Village by
any Federal, State or municipality, or agent thereof, by reason of his office,
employment or agency in the Village.
      4.   An investigation of any other officer, employee or agent of the
Village by any Federal, state or municipality, or agency thereof, to which such
officer, employee or agent may be subjected to by reason of another officer's,
employee's or agent's duties or actions as such Village officer, employee or
agent.
   B.   Reimbursement For Counsel: No officer, employee or agent of the Village
shall be entitled to reimbursement for counsel when his action was done with
malice or wilful misconduct. No officer, employee or agent of the Village shall
have further use of appointed counsel or be reimbursed where there is a finding
of guilty against him in a criminal or quasi-criminal action or wilful
misconduct in a civil action.
   C.   Matter Of Right: The appointment of counsel and payment of costs shall
not be a matter of right of any officer, employee or agent, but is a matter in
the sole discretion of the Village. Reimbursement, however, shall be a matter
of right to any officer, employee or agent and shall cover only those duties or
actions committed within the course of employment or by the nature of the
office, employment or agency held.
   D.   Appointment Of Counsel: The appointment of counsel shall be made by the
President, with the advice and consent of the Board of Trustees. The President,
with the consent of the Board of Trustees, may terminate such appointment at
any time. Appointed counsel shall be paid up to time his employment is
terminated. No officer, employee or agent shall be entitled to reimbursement
unless he notifies the Clerk and Village Attorney in writing within fifteen
(15) days after receiving first notice that a claim, action or investigation is
being made or instituted against him. No officer, employee or agent shall be
entitled to reimbursement if he does not accept the offer of appointed counsel.
No officer, employee or agent shall be entitled to reimbursement if he refuses
to cooperate in the investigation of any matter or claim, including the taking
of a polygraph examination or breathalyzer test. No officer, employee or agent
shall be entitled to reimbursement if he does not cooperate in the defense of
the suit, action or claim.
   E.   Right And Duty To Defend: The Village shall have the right and duty to
defend any suit against any officer, employee or agent, or any former officer,
employee or agent, for breach of duty made against that person by reason of any
negligent act, error or omission, including misfeasance, malfeasance and
nonfeasance, or any other claim, arising out of the scope of duties of said
person. (1996 Code)
1-8-4: INDEMNIFICATION:
   A.   Generally: The Village shall indemnify and hold harmless any officer,
employee or agent of the Village, or any former officer, employee or agent of
the Village, from any and all liability, lawsuits or damages any such person
may suffer as a result of claims, demands, costs or judgment against him for
actions or inactions within the scope of his employment or duties, and the
Village shall further indemnify him for any damages awarded or monies paid in
compromise or settlement. No indemnification shall be made where there is
adequate insurance, nor where there is a finding of guilty in a criminal or
quasi-criminal case and fines or penalties are assessed.
   B.   Persons Entitled To Indemnification: No officer, employee or agent of
the Village, or former officer, employee or agent of the Village, shall be
entitled to indemnification unless he notifies the Village Clerk and Village
Attorney in writing within fifteen (15) days after receiving first notice that
a claim, action or investigation is being made or instituted against him. No
officer, employee or agent of the Village, or former officer, employee or agent
of the Village, shall be entitled to indemnification if he does not accept the
offer of appointed counsel. No officer, employee or agent of the Village, or
former officer, employee or agent of the Village, shall be entitled to
indemnification if he refuses to cooperate in the investigation of any matter
or claim, including the taking of a polygraph examination or breathalyzer test.
No officer, employee or agent of the Village, or former officer, employee or
agent of the Village, shall be entitled to indemnification if he does not
cooperate in the defense of the suit, action or claim. (1996 Code)
1-8-5: APPLICABILITY OF CHAPTER:
This Chapter shall apply to any claims heretofore or hereafter made coming
within the terms of the provisions of this Chapter. (1996 Code)
