CHAPTER 1
MISCELLANEOUS TRAFFIC PROVISIONS
SECTION:
6-1-1: Speed Restrictions
6-1-2: Speed Limits On Certain Streets
6-1-3: Reckless And Negligent Driving
6-1-4: Parking Restrictions
6-1-5: Traffic Movement Regulations
6-1-5-1: One-Way Streets
6-1-5-2: No Turns
6-1-6: Stop Streets
6-1-1: SPEED RESTRICTIONS:
   A.   Generally: No person shall drive any vehicle upon any public highway,
road or street in the Village at a speed which:
      1.   Is greater than is reasonable and proper with regard to traffic
conditions and the use of the highway or endangers the safety of any person or
property; or
      2.   Is greater than the applicable maximum speed limit established by
this section.
The fact that the speed of a vehicle does not exceed the applicable maximum
speed limit does not relieve the driver from the duty to decrease speed when
approaching and crossing an intersection, when approaching and going around a
curve, when approaching a hillcrest, when traveling upon any narrow or winding
roadway or when special hazard exists with respect to pedestrians or other
traffic or by reason of weather or highway conditions and speed shall be
decreased as may be necessary to avoid colliding with any person or vehicle on
or entering the highway in compliance with legal requirements and the duty of
all persons to use due care. (Ord. 18, 11-14-1963)
   B.   Maximum Speed Limit: The maximum speed limit for all vehicles in the
Village is thirty (30) miles per hour on all streets and roadways but shall not
be applicable to the following streets:
   Delany Road
   Dilleys Road
   Kilbourne Road
   Route 173
   Russell Road
   State Route 41
   Wadsworth Road
   Yorkhouse Road
   21st Street
   C.   Penalty: Any violation of this section shall subject the violator to
the penalties set forth in section
1-4-1 of this Code. (Ord. 18, 11-14-1963; amd. 1996 Code)
6-1-2: SPEED LIMITS ON CERTAIN STREETS:
   A.   The speed limit for 21st Street between Delany and Kilbourne Roads is
hereby established at twenty five (25) miles per hour.
   B.   The speed limit for Delany Road (north of Illinois 173) is hereby
established at thirty five (35) miles per hour. (Ord. 2007-742, 9-18-2007)
6-1-3: RECKLESS AND NEGLIGENT DRIVING:
   A.   Offense: It shall be unlawful to operate any vehicle in the Village in
a reckless or wanton manner or in a careless manner or in a negligent manner or
as so to unnecessarily endanger life and property. (Ord. 18, 11-14-1963)
   B.   Penalty: Any violation of this section shall subject the violator to
the penalties set forth in section
1-4-1 of this Code. (1996 Code)
6-1-4: PARKING RESTRICTIONS:
   A.   Caroline Avenue: Vehicular parking is only permitted on the west side
of Caroline Avenue in designated parking/drive areas from the north side of
Wadsworth Road northerly to a point two hundred forty five feet (245') north of
the intersection of Caroline Avenue and Wadsworth Road.
   B.   McCarthy Road: It shall be unlawful to park any motor vehicle on any
portion of McCarthy Road.
   C.   Chicago Avenue: It shall be unlawful to park any motor vehicle on
Chicago Avenue from Yorkhouse Road and extended northerly for a distance of one
thousand feet (1,000').
   D.   Schlosser Court: It shall be unlawful to park any motor vehicle on
Schlosser Court from its western terminus easterly for a distance of two
hundred fifty feet (250'). This prohibition shall not apply to Village
residents who reside on Schlosser Court or their invited guests.
   E.   Southeast District: It shall be unlawful to park any motor vehicle on
any improved or unimproved road or right-of-way within that portion of the
Southeast District Neighborhood that is described as follows: Wadsworth Road to
the north, the Union Pacific Railroad to the west, Beach Road to the south; and
Bayonne Avenue to the east. This prohibition shall not apply to Village
residents who reside in said neighborhood or their invited guests. In addition
to the penalties authorized by subsection I of this section, any vehicle parked
in violation of this subsection is declared a nuisance and a hazard to public
safety, and any police officer of the Village is authorized to remove, or
contract for the removal of, the vehicle to a place of storage at the expense
of the owner of the vehicle, not to be released until the actual charges and
costs of towing and storage are paid in full or in accordance with applicable
State law.
   F.   Mulberry Lane: It shall be unlawful to park any motor vehicle on
Mulberry Lane from Dilleys Road to Thornapple Lane.
   G.   Hanssen Road: It shall be unlawful to park any motor vehicle on Hanssen
Road from U.S. Highway 41 westerly a distance of six hundred feet (600').
   H.   Mill Creek Woodlands Subdivision: It shall be unlawful to park any
motor vehicle on Old Orchard Drive, Cherrywood Lane or Thornmeadow Circle. This
prohibition shall not apply to Village residents who reside in said
neighborhood or their invited guests.
   I.   Red Oak Terrace: It shall be unlawful to park any motor vehicle on Red
Oak Terrace. This prohibition shall not apply to village residents who reside
along said street or their invited guests.
   J.   Penalty: Any violation of this section shall subject the violator to
the penalties set forth in section
1-4-1 of this Code. (Ord. 2004-656, 4-20-2004; Ord. 2012-865, 5-1-2012; Ord.
2012-870, 5-15-2012; Ord. 2012-878, 8-21-2012; Ord. 2013-903, 7-16-2013; Ord.
2017-1010, 6-20-2017; Ord. 2019-1074, 10-15-2019)
6-1-5: TRAFFIC MOVEMENT REGULATIONS:
6-1-5-1: ONE-WAY STREETS:
The following streets are hereby designated for one-way traffic only:
West Hart Street from one hundred forty feet (140') west of North Bayonne
Avenue to North Bayonne Avenue, eastbound traffic only. (Ord. 2010-823, 9-7-
2010)
6-1-5-2: NO TURNS:
Turns by nonemergency vehicles shall be and are hereby prohibited at the
following intersections, and any person violating the provisions of this
section shall be subject to a fine as established by the annual fee ordinance
for each offense:
Westbound West Hart Street from North Bayonne Avenue. (Ord. 2010-823, 9-7-2010)
6-1-6: STOP STREETS:
Except when directed to proceed by a police officer or traffic control signal,
every driver of a vehicle approaching a stop intersection indicated by a stop
sign shall stop at a clearly marked stop line, but if none, before entering the
crosswalk on the near side of the intersection, or if none, then at the point
nearest the intersecting roadway where the driver has a view of approaching
traffic on the intersecting roadway before entering the intersection. After
having stopped, the driver shall yield the right-of-way to any vehicle which
has entered the intersection from another roadway or which is approaching so
closely on the roadway as to constitute an immediate hazard during the time
when the driver is moving across or within the intersection, but said driver
having so yielded may proceed at such time as a safe interval occurs.
The stop sign intersections are as follows:

CHAPTER 2
TRUCKS AND RESTRICTED VEHICLES
SECTION:
6-2-1: Truck Traffic
6-2-2: Restricted Vehicles
6-2-1: TRUCK TRAFFIC:
   A.   Weight Restrictions: It shall be unlawful to drive any truck (every
motor vehicle designed, used or maintained primarily for the transportation of
property) with a gross weight, including the vehicle and load, in excess of
twelve thousand (12,000) pounds or with a class F or heavier license plate on
any road within the village which is within its jurisdiction except as
otherwise permitted.
   B.   Permitted Vehicles: The prohibition in subsection A of this section
shall not apply to fire, police or other emergency vehicles, village owned
vehicles, school buses, public transit vehicles, garbage trucks on scheduled
routes within the village or public utility vehicles. In addition, this
prohibition shall not apply to trucks which exceed the above weight limit
provided that the driver has a valid bill of lading for a delivery or pick up
to a residence, business or construction site within the village and the truck
traverses those village roads which are reasonably necessary for ingress or
egress to that destination and provided that the truck shall use nonvillage
roads whenever practicable. (Ord. 93-384, 3-16-1993)
   C.   Overnight Parking: No truck with a gross weight, including vehicle and
load, in excess of twelve thousand (12,000) pounds shall be parked in view of
the public overnight in any area which is zoned residential within the village.
This prohibition shall apply to all properties that are zoned SD, SE, SR or any
other residential zoning district which may hereafter be created. (Ord. 2002-
612, 10-15-2002, eff. 1-15-2003)
   D.   Limitation Exceptions: The limitations contained in subsection B of
this section shall not apply to truck traffic on Delany Road, Yorkhouse Road,
Kilbourne Road, Wadsworth Road, U.S. Route 41, Dilleys Road south of Wadsworth
Road, Route 173 and that portion of Adams Road perpendicular to and easterly of
Delany Road for a distance of two thousand two hundred (2,200) linear feet. As
to these roads, no person shall drive any motor vehicle with a weight,
including load, in excess of that permitted by applicable state law for driving
on improved highways or with its weight distributed in a manner not conforming
with applicable state law. (Ord. 93-384, 3-16-1993)
   E.   Local Class II Truck Routes:
      1.   A class II truck route is hereby established for a distance of point
three (0.3) mile on that portion of Adams Road between Delany Road easterly to,
and westerly of, and not including, the bridge on Adams Road.
      2.   A class II truck route is hereby established on that portion of
Delany Road between Illinois Route 173 to a point one point five (1.5) miles
north of said intersection of Delany Road and Illinois Route 173.
   F.   Penalty: Any violation of this section shall subject the violator to
the penalties set forth in section
1-4-1 of this code. (Ord. 2006-709, 10-17-2006)
6-2-2: RESTRICTED VEHICLES:
   A.   Determination By Chairman: Whenever the chairman of the road and bridge
committee of the village board of trustees determines that because of
deterioration, rain, snow or other climatic conditions, any village street or
road, or portions of any street or road, will be seriously damaged or destroyed
by the use of certain vehicles thereon, the chairman shall file a report of
such determination in the office of the village clerk.
   B.   Filing Of Report: The report of the chairman of the road and bridge
committee shall first identify by accurate description the streets or roads, or
portions of streets or roads, the chairman finds to be in danger of destruction
or damage and, further, the report shall state whether or not said highways or
portions thereof are to be closed to vehicular traffic or restricted in use as
to type of vehicle or as to weight of vehicle and load. The report shall
further state the period of time the restriction shall be in effect; provided,
however, that no such restriction shall be in effect for a period of time
longer than ninety (90) days in any one calendar year.
   C.   Erection Of Signs: Within five (5) days after the filing of the report
as provided in subsection A of this section, the chairman of the road and
bridge committee shall cause to be erected and maintained signs at each end of
the street or portions thereof named in such report, which signs shall be so
located in sufficient number to acquaint operators or owners of vehicles using
the said streets or portions thereof of the restrictions on use which shall be
designated on the signs.
   D.   Use Prohibited: It is unlawful for any person to drive or move or for
the owner to cause or knowingly permit to be driven or moved on any village
street or road in the village any vehicle whose use has been determined to be
damaging to the highway and whose use is prohibited by the signs so erected and
maintained.
   E.   Through Truck Traffic Prohibited: All trucks operated on village
streets constructed of bituminous pavement on a gravel base or upon gravel
streets which are so posted shall be limited to local travel only and through
truck travel on such streets is hereby expressly prohibited. (Ord. 64, 5-7-
1973)
   F.   Penalty: Whenever any vehicle is operating in violation of the
provisions of this section, the owner or driver, or both, of such vehicle shall
be deemed guilty of such violation and either or both the owner and the driver
of such vehicle may be prosecuted for such violation. Any person who violates
the provisions of this section shall be subject to penalty as provided in
section
1-4-1 of this code. (Ord. 64, 5-7-1973; amd. 1996 Code)
CHAPTER 3
SNOWMOBILES
SECTION:
6-3-1: Definitions
6-3-2: Regulations
6-3-3: Exceptions
6-3-4: Equipment Required
6-3-5: Penalty
6-3-1: DEFINITIONS:
As used in this Chapter, the following words and terms shall have the meanings
ascribed to them in this Section:
OPERATE: To control the operation of a snowmobile.
OPERATOR: A person who operates or is in actual control of a snowmobile.
SNOWMOBILE: A self-propelled vehicle designed for travel on snow or ice in a
natural terrain steered by wheels, skis or runners. (Ord. 52, 1-9-1971)
6-3-2: REGULATIONS:
It shall be unlawful for any person to operate a snowmobile under the following
circumstances:
   A.   On private property of another without the express permission to do so
by the owner or occupant of said property.
   B.   On public school grounds, park property, playgrounds, recreational
areas and golf courses without express provision or permission to do so by the
proper public authority.
   C.   In a manner so as to create loud, unnecessary or unusual noise so as to
disturb or interfere with the peace and quiet of other persons.
   D.   In a careless, reckless or negligent manner so as to endanger the
safety of any person or the property of any other person.
   E.   Within the right of way of any public street or roadway.
   F.   Between the hours of eleven o'clock (11:00) P.M. to seven o'clock (7:
00) A.M. (Ord. 52, 1-9-1971)
6-3-3: EXCEPTIONS:
When it becomes necessary to cross a public street or roadway, the operator
shall stop the snowmobile before crossing and shall yield the right of way to
vehicular traffic. (Ord. 52, 1-9-1971)
6-3-4: EQUIPMENT REQUIRED:
All snowmobiles operated within the Village shall have the following equipment:
   A.   Mufflers: Mufflers which are properly attached and which reduce the
noise of operation of the vehicle to the minimum noise necessary for operating
the vehicle and no person shall use a muffler cutout bypass or similar device
on said vehicle.
   B.   Brakes; Headlight; Taillight: Adequate brakes in good working condition
and at least one headlight and one taillight.
   C.   Dead-Man Throttle: A safety or so-called "dead man" throttle in
operating condition. A safety or "dead man" throttle is defined as a device
which, when pressure is removed from the accelerator or throttle, causes the
motor to be disengaged from driving track. (Ord. 52, 1-9-1971)
6-3-5: PENALTY:
Any violation of this Chapter shall subject the violator to the penalties set
forth in Section
1-4-1 of this Code. (1996 Code)
CHAPTER 4
OFF-ROAD MOTORIZED VEHICLES
SECTION:
6-4-1: Definitions
6-4-2: Regulations
6-4-3: Exception
6-4-4: Equipment Required
6-4-5: Penalty
6-4-1: DEFINITIONS:
As used in this Chapter, the following words and terms shall have the meanings
ascribed to them in this Section:
OFF-ROAD MOTORIZED VEHICLES: A self-propelled, motorized vehicle designed for
travel on natural terrain or on roadways and which are not approved and
licensed for operation on the public highways of the State of Illinois.
OPERATE: To control the operation of an off-road motorized vehicle.
OPERATOR: A person who operates or is in actual control of an off-road
motorized vehicle. (Ord. 197, 7-15-1985)
6-4-2: REGULATIONS:
It shall be unlawful for any person to operate an off-road motorized vehicle
under the following circumstances:
   A.   On private property of another without the express permission to do so
by the owner or occupant of said property.
   B.   On public school grounds, park property, playgrounds, recreational
areas and golf courses without express provision or permission to do so by the
proper public authority.
   C.   In a manner so as to create loud, unnecessary or unusual noise so as to
disturb or interfere with the peace and quiet of other persons.
   D.   In a careless, reckless or negligent manner so as to endanger the
safety of any person or the property of any other person.
   E.   Within the right of way of any public street or roadway.
   F.   Between the hours of eleven o'clock (11:00) P.M. to seven o'clock (7:
00) A.M. (Ord. 197, 7-15-1985)
6-4-3: EXCEPTION:
When it becomes necessary to cross a public street or roadway, the operator
shall stop the off-road motorized vehicle before crossing and shall yield the
right of way to vehicular traffic. (Ord. 197, 7-15-1987)
6-4-4: EQUIPMENT REQUIRED:
All off-road motorized vehicles operated within the Village shall have the
following equipment:
   A.   Mufflers: Mufflers which are properly attached and which reduce the
noise of operation of the vehicle to the minimum noise necessary for operating
the vehicle and no person shall use a muffler cutting bypass or similar device
on said vehicle.
   B.   Brakes: Adequate brakes in good working condition. (Ord. 197, 7-15-
1985)
6-4-5: PENALTY:
Any violation of this Chapter shall subject the violator to the penalties set
forth in Section
1-4-1 of this Code. (1996 Code)
CHAPTER 5
ABANDONED OR INOPERATIVE MOTOR VEHICLES
SECTION:
6-5-1: Inoperative Vehicles Declared Nuisance
6-5-2: Prohibited On Any Street Or Way
6-5-3: Unattended For Forty Eight Hours
6-5-4: Parking Following Snowfall
6-5-5: Inoperable Motor Vehicles
6-5-6: Abandonment Of Vehicles Prohibited
6-5-7: Penalty
6-5-1: INOPERATIVE VEHICLES DECLARED NUISANCE:
The outside storage of inoperative vehicles as defined in 65 Illinois Compiled
Statutes 5/11-40-3, except on property in a zone in which a junk yard or outer
salvage yard is permitted under the provisions of Title 10 of this Code and
which meets the standards imposed by Title 10, is hereby declared to be a
public nuisance and it shall be unlawful for any person to park, store or leave
any vehicle on private property in the Village so as to cause a nuisance as
herein defined. (Ord. 150, 3-9-1981)
6-5-2: PROHIBITED ON ANY STREET OR WAY:
It shall be unlawful for any person to park, store or leave any licensed or
unlicensed motor vehicle or part(s) thereof which is in a junked, wrecked,
partially dismantled, inoperative or abandoned condition, whether attended or
not, upon any part of any street or way within the Village at any time. (Ord.
150, 3-9-1981)
6-5-3: UNATTENDED FOR FORTY EIGHT HOURS:
It shall be unlawful for any person to park, store or leave any licensed or
unlicensed vehicle on public streets located within the Village for a period of
in excess of forty eight (48) hours. Any vehicle remaining unattended on a
public street continuously for a period of forty eight (48) hours shall be
deemed an abandoned vehicle. (Ord. 150, 3-9-1981)
6-5-4: PARKING FOLLOWING SNOWFALL:
It shall be unlawful to leave a vehicle unattended on a public street in the
Village following a snowfall requiring snow removal and any vehicle left
unattended on a public street in the Village following a snowfall requiring
snow removal by the Village shall be deemed an abandoned vehicle. An abandoned
motor vehicle as referred to in this Section shall be deemed a hazard to the
public health, safety and welfare and shall be subject to immediate removal by
Village authorities without prior notice and hearing. (Ord. 150, 3-9-1981)
6-5-5: INOPERABLE MOTOR VEHICLES:
   A.   Declared Nuisance: All inoperable motor vehicles, whether on public or
private property and in view of the general public, are a nuisance. The failure
of any person to obey a notice received from the Village, which states that
such person is to dispose of any inoperable motor vehicles or parts under his
control, and which authorizes its removal by the appropriate law enforcement
agency or its designee of any such inoperable motor vehicle or parts thereafter
seven (7) days from the issuance of the Village notice, shall be a violation of
this Section, and subject the violator to the penalties provided in Section
1-4-1. However, nothing in this Section shall apply to any motor vehicle that
is kept within a building when not in use, to operable historic vehicles over
twenty five (25) years of age, or to a motor vehicle on the premises of a place
of business engaged in the wrecking or junking of motor vehicles.
   B.   Definition: As used in this Section, "inoperable motor vehicle" means
any motor vehicle from which, for a period of at least seven (7) days, the
engine, wheels or other parts have been removed, or on which the engine, wheels
or other parts have been altered, damaged or otherwise so treated that the
vehicle is incapable of being driven under its own motor power. "Inoperable
motor vehicle" shall not include a motor vehicle which has been rendered
temporarily incapable of being driven under its own motor power in order to
perform ordinary service or repair operations, which are done on a timely
basis. (1996 Code)
6-5-6: ABANDONMENT OF VEHICLES PROHIBITED:
   A.   The abandonment of a vehicle or any part thereof on any highway, road,
or street within the Village is unlawful and subject to penalties as set forth
in Section
1-4-1.
   B.   The abandonment of a vehicle or any part thereof on private or public
property, other than a highway, street, or road, in view of the general public,
anywhere in the Village is unlawful except on property of the owner or bailee
of such abandoned vehicle. A vehicle or any part thereof so abandoned on
private property shall be authorized for removal, by a law enforcement agency
having jurisdiction, after a waiting period of seven (7) days or more, or may
be removed immediately if determined to be a hazardous dilapidated motor
vehicle under section 11-40-3.1 of the Illinois Municipal Code. A violation of
this Section is subject to penalties as set forth in Section
1-4-1 of this Code.
   C.   Any such abandoned vehicle shall be removed, stored, sold, and/or
disposed of in accordance with 625 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/4-201 et seq.
(1996 Code)
6-5-7: PENALTY:
Any violation of this Chapter shall subject the violator to the penalties set
forth in Section
1-4-1 of this Code. (1996 Code)
TITLE 7
PUBLIC WAYS AND PROPERTY
Street Regulations   1
Construction Of Facilities In The Rights-Of-Way   2
Park Regulations   3
CHAPTER 1
STREET REGULATIONS
SECTION:
7-1-1: Moving Certain Vehicles, Permit Required
7-1-2: Spilling Materials On Streets
7-1-3: Use After Snowfall
7-1-1: MOVING CERTAIN VEHICLES, PERMIT REQUIRED:
Any person desiring to move a steamroller, Caterpillar tractor, lug vehicle or
any other heavy machinery over the streets of the village shall first obtain a
permit from the village, which permit shall define the route to be traversed.
(Ord. 76, 7-1-1974)
7-1-2: SPILLING MATERIALS ON STREETS:
   A.   Vehicle To Be Tight: Any person engaged in transporting upon any street
material likely to shift, fall or be blown upon the streets shall convey and
carry the same in a tight body.
   B.   Overloading: No person shall cause any vehicle to be loaded so that the
contents can be scattered in any street or any other public place.
   C.   Dirt From Tires: No person shall cause the wheels of any car or vehicle
to become covered or clogged with earth in such a manner that such earth is
scattered on any street or any other public place. It shall be the duty of any
person in control of any such cart or vehicle to gather up and remove such
earth at once. (Ord. 76, 7-1-1974)
   D.   Repair Of Damage: If any person, by violation of the terms of this
section, breaks or otherwise injures any street or causes debris to be
scattered on streets of the village, they shall, within twenty four (24) hours
after being notified by the village of such offense, cause the same to be
repaired, mended and cleaned under the direction and to the satisfaction of the
compliance officer. (Ord. 76, 7-1-1974; amd. 1996 Code)
   E.   Sticky Or Foreign Substance: No person shall drive or move a vehicle in
such a manner to cause any sticky substance or other foreign matter to be
deposited upon or attached to any public street or private property. (Ord.
2004-653, 3-2-2004)
   F.   Penalty: Any violation of this section shall subject the violator to
the penalties set forth in section
1-4-1 of this code. (1996 Code; amd. Ord. 2004-653, 3-2-2004)
7-1-3: USE AFTER SNOWFALL:
   A.   Parking: It shall be unlawful for a motor vehicle, unattended by a
driver, to be parked upon the public right of way of any street in the village
within a forty eight (48) hour period following a two inch (2") snowfall.
   B.   Snow From Driveways, Etc.: It shall be unlawful for snow removal from
private driveways or public rights of way to be deposited on the paved or
traveled portion of any public street or right of way in the village. (Ord.
193, 2-11-1985)
   C.   Penalty: Any violation of this section shall subject the violator to
the penalties set forth in section
1-4-1 of this code. (1996 Code)
CHAPTER 2
CONSTRUCTION OF FACILITIES IN THE RIGHTS-OF-WAY
SECTION:
7-2-1: Purpose And Scope

7-2-18: Removal, Relocation Or Modifications
