CHAPTER 1
TITLE AND PURPOSE
SECTION:
12-1-1: Title
12-1-2: Purpose
12-1-1: TITLE:
This Title shall be known, cited and referred to as the WADSWORTH LANDSCAPE
ORDINANCE. (Ord. 97-473, 4-1-1997)
12-1-2: PURPOSE:
The natural landscape of the Wadsworth area is one of the Village's most valued
assets. It is a unique combination of natural and manmade features adapted
during the nineteenth and early twentieth centuries to an agrarian way of life.
The second half of the twentieth century has seen the beginning of a process of
development and change from a farm community to a low density suburban
community. It is the intent of this Title to protect and preserve those
features of the natural and agrarian landscape which contribute to the beauty
and charm of this Village setting and to regulate new development so that the
benefits of a well-landscaped environment are extended to all present and
future residents of the Village. Specifically this Title is adopted for the
following purposes:
   A.   To protect existing trees and forests and to secure for the residents
of Wadsworth the environmental and aesthetic benefits that such trees and
forests provide and to require the replacement of such trees and forests which
cannot as a practical matter be preserved.
   B.   To further implement the Wadsworth subdivision regulations 1  by
establishing standards for the landscaping of new subdivisions and planned unit
developments.
   C.   To further implement the natural resource protection and scenic
corridor provisions of the Wadsworth Zoning Ordinance 2  by establishing
standards for the landscaping of such areas.
   D.   To establish standards and regulations for the landscaping of business
and industries.
   E.   To protect the natural habitat of animal species indigenous to
Wadsworth environments.
   F.   To establish standards and regulations for preparation of landscape
plans, and the installation and maintenance of plant materials.
   G.   To provide for the removal of diseased or unsafe trees and other plant
materials, which contribute to unsafe or unhealthy environmental conditions.
   H.   To promote and protect the public health, safety, comfort, convenience,
and general welfare of the people of Wadsworth. (Ord. 97-473, 4-1-1997)
 
Notes
1 1. See Title 11 of this Code.
2 2. See Title 10 of this Code.
CHAPTER 2
DEFINITIONS
SECTION:
12-2-1: Rules Of Construction
12-2-2: Definitions And Abbreviations
12-2-1: RULES OF CONSTRUCTION:
   A.   Tense: Words used in the present tense shall include the future tense.
   B.   Plural: Words used in the singular shall include the plural, and in the
plural the singular.
   C.   Gender: The masculine gender includes the feminine and the neuter.
   D.   Usage:
      1.   The words "shall" and "will" are mandatory and not discretionary.
      2.   The word "may" is permissive.
      3.   The word "lot" shall mean a zoning lot, unless otherwise defined
herein.
      4.   The word "structure" shall include the word "building".
      5.   The phrase "used for" shall include the phrases "intended for",
"designed for", "occupied for", "maintained for", and "arranged for".
   E.   Measurements And Standards:
      1.   All measured distances, expressed in feet, shall be to the nearest
foot; if a fraction is one-half foot (1/2') or less, the full number next below
shall be used. If a fraction is more than one-half foot (1/2'), the next full
number above shall be used.
      2.   All measurements expressed in feet and inches shall be to the
nearest inch; if fraction is one-half inch (1/2") or less, the full number next
below shall be used. If a fraction is more than one-half inch (1/2"), the next
full number above shall be used.
      3.   Any standard herein which, when applied, results in the requirement
of a fraction part of a tree or other plant shall be deemed to require the next
whole number of such trees or other plants when the fraction, however
expressed, is one- half (1/2) or more; otherwise use the next lower number.
(Ord. 97-473, 4-1-1997)
12-2-2: DEFINITIONS AND ABBREVIATIONS:
In the construction of this Title the definitions contained herein shall be
observed and applied except when the context clearly indicates otherwise. Also,
abbreviations, initials, and symbols used in the text, tables, exhibits, and
forms shall have the meanings ascribed to them herein.
BB: Balled and burlapped.
BR: Bare root.
CALIPER: The diameter size of trees. The caliper of the trunk shall be taken
six inches (6") above the ground up to and including four inch (4") caliper
size, and twelve inches (12") above the ground for larger sizes.
CANOPY TREE: A descriptive term referring to large, single trunk, outwardly
branching trees reaching a mature height of at least thirty feet (30').
DBH: The diameter size of trees at breast height. Breast height measured at
four and one-half feet (41/2').
DECIDUOUS TREE (Or Other Plant): Any tree or other plant which sheds its leaves
or needles at a particular season of the year.
DEVELOPER: The owner of a lot or other parcel of land or his agent engaged in
the subdivision of land and/or the construction of improvements to land with
the intention of selling to another person the lots so subdivided or the land
so improved.
DRIP LINE: The perimeter of the circular area surrounding the trunk of a tree
measured as one foot (1') of radius from the trunk for each one inch (1") of
diameter at breast height.
EVERGREEN TREE (Or Other Plant): Any tree or other plant which retains its
leaves or needles and remains green throughout the year.
GROUND COVER: A spreading plant with a height less than one foot (1'). Ground
cover plants are often planted in dense grouping to control erosion or to
provide ornamental surface.
LANDSCAPE ARCHITECT: Any person trained or educated as a landscape architect
who is a registered landscape architect with the State of Illinois.
ORNAMENTAL TREE: A tree generally having a mature height of less than twenty
five feet (25'), valued for one or more aesthetic characteristics such as
overall form, quality of bark, flowers, color of green foliage, fall color, or
berries.
OWNER: The person or persons who are the record title holders of a parcel of
land.
PUD: Planned unit development.
PERSON: Any individual, corporation, partnership, association, or any other
legal entity, or any agent, servant, officer or employee thereof.
SHRUB: A small woody plant, generally less than twelve feet (12') in height
having either many trunks or stems or a pattern of branching which starts close
to the ground. Shrubs may be either deciduous or evergreen. Some shrubs are
raised or pruned to resemble small trees and are called herein "tree-form"
shrubs.
SUBDIVIDER: Any person subdividing land.
TREE: Any large woody plant having, characteristically, a single upright trunk
or stem. Some large trees have multiple trunks and are here described as
clumped or "clump form" trees.
TURF: An area of the surface of the ground densely planted with grasses or
similar plants; lawn.
VILLAGE: Village of Wadsworth, Illinois.
VILLAGE FORESTER: A person appointed as Village Forester by the Village Board.
(Ord. 97-473, 4-1-1997)
CHAPTER 3
SCOPE AND REGULATION
SECTION:
12-3-1: Standards And Regulations
12-3-1: STANDARDS AND REGULATIONS:
The standards and regulations of this title shall be applicable to the
following developments, acts, or situations occurring within the village:
   A.   Tree Protection: The standards and regulations for the protection of
existing trees and the replacement of removed or destroyed trees shall be
applicable to all areas of the village as set forth in chapter 4 of this title
and this title generally.
   B.   New Subdivisions: All new subdivisions and planned unit developments
shall be landscaped in accordance with the standards and regulations of chapter
5 of this title and this title generally. (Ord. 97-473, 4-1-1997)
   C.   Commercial Uses: All newly constructed, reconstructed or enlarged uses
in the B business, CR commercial recreation, OR office and research and LI, LI-
1, and LI-2 light industrial districts, and the PL public land district shall
be landscaped in accordance with the standards and regulations of chapter 5 of
this title and this title generally. (Ord. 2009-803, 12-15-2009)
   D.   Conditional Uses: All uses for which a conditional use permit is
required under the Wadsworth zoning ordinance 1  shall be landscaped in
accordance with the standards and regulations herein. See also subsection
10-5-4A of this code.
   E.   Uses In Overlay Districts: All uses which are required to have site
plan review and approval prior to being permitted in overlay districts as shown
in section
10-4-4, table 1-A of this code. See also subsections
10-4-3B2 and
10-5-4A of this code.
   F.   Uses In Scenic Corridors: That portion of any lot which extends into a
scenic corridor overlay district shall be landscaped in accordance with the
standards and regulations herein. (Ord. 97-473, 4-1-1997)
 
Notes
1 1. See title 10 of this code.
CHAPTER 4
PROTECTION AND REPLACEMENT OF EXISTING TREES
SECTION:
12-4-1: Protected Trees
12-4-2: Tree Protection During Construction
12-4-3: Prior Destruction Or Removal
12-4-4: Tree Replacement Standards
12-4-5: Tree Removal Permit Required
12-4-6: Exceptions
12-4-1: PROTECTED TREES:
   A.   Tree Cutting And Removal: Within the territorial limits of the Village
no person shall, without first obtaining a permit, remove or relocate to any
other site a tree or trees as described herein.
      1.   Any tree with a trunk diameter of six inches (6") or greater, DBH,
located in a "mature woodland" as defined by Section
10-2-3 of this Code, and which is subject to the natural resource protection
standards for forests provided for in subsection
10-5-3E of this Code.
      2.   Any tree with a trunk diameter of three inches (3") or greater, DBH,
located in a "young woodland" as defined by Section
10-2-3 of this Code, and which is subject to the natural resource protection
standards for forests provided for in subsection
10-5-3E of this Code.
      3.   Any other protected tree within the territorial limits of the
Village having a trunk diameter of ten inches (10") or greater, DBH.
   B.   Assaults On Trees:
      1.   No tree identified above shall be deliberately or accidentally
damaged or injured including damage or injury caused by the operation of
construction or maintenance machinery or motor vehicles.
      2.   No wires, cables, lights, signs or similar items may be attached to
any tree located in the public right of way or on public land except by
permission of the Village or the public agency owning the land upon which the
tree is located.
      3.   Where a tree is damaged so as to be unsafe, as determined by the
Village Forester, it shall be removed and replaced in accordance with the
replacement standards of Section
12-4-4 of this Chapter, by the person causing the damage or injury. (Ord. 97-
473, 4-1-1997)
12-4-2: TREE PROTECTION DURING CONSTRUCTION:
   A.   During Construction:
      1.   Protected trees as described in Section
12-4-1 of this Chapter shall be protected during all on-site construction
activities either by providing temporary fencing at the drip line and excluding
therefrom all construction equipment and materials storage, or by adhering to
the trunk vertical timbers in cases where there is not sufficient room for drip
line protection.
      2.   Construction activities in the vicinity of some species of trees
constitutes an assault, the effect of which can be mitigated by a variety of
practices including pruning, root pruning, feeding and tunneling for the
installation of utilities. Where failure to undertake such practices results in
the loss of a tree it shall be replaced in accordance with the replacement
standards set forth in Section
12-4-4 of this Chapter.
   B.   Post-Construction: The post-construction protection of mature and young
woodlands shall be in accordance with the resource protection standards of the
Wadsworth Zoning Ordinance 1 . (Ord. 97-473, 4-1-1997)
 
Notes
1 1. See Title 10 of this Code.
12-4-3: PRIOR DESTRUCTION OR REMOVAL:
If during the course of the review of an application for an annexation to or a
development within the Village, it shall be determined that mature trees, or
mature or young woodlands, have been cut or relocated from the site prior to
the application for an annexation or a development, the net result of which
would be to frustrate or interfere with the application of a site capacity
analysis required under Section
10-5-3 of this Code, then, in that event, the Village shall treat the
annexation or development as if the trees were still existing on the site, and
require all appropriate site capacity calculations to be so applied. In
addition, as a condition of approval of the annexation or development, the
Village shall require that the developer replenish the site with like species
which aggregate to the full sum of the diameter of the trees which have been
removed. (Ord. 97-473, 4-1-1997)
12-4-4: TREE REPLACEMENT STANDARDS:
   A.   Standard: When a permit is issued to remove tree(s), the permittee
shall be required to plant replacement trees for every tree removed after the
fifth tree for individual home sites and for every tree removed after the third
tree for other sites. The Village Forester may reduce the required amount of
replacement trees if he determines that strict compliance with this requirement
is impossible or not reasonably practical and a reduced amount of replanting
would still fulfill the purpose and intent of this Title. Tree replacements
will be of like species or other species approved by the Village Forester and
the number and size of which shall be in accordance with the following table:
Tree Removed In Young Woodlands Replacement Trees
Tree Removed In Young Woodlands Replacement Trees
1–4" to 6", DBH               1–3" caliper
1–Over 6", DBH                1–4" caliper or 2–3" caliper
In Mature Woodlands
1–3" to 5", DBH               1–3" caliper
1–6" to 12", DBH              2–3" caliper
1–Over 12", DBH               3–4" caliper
All Other Trees
1–10" to 14", DBH             3–4" caliper
1–Over 14", DBH               4–4" caliper
 
   B.   Exception: The natural resource protection standards of the Wadsworth
Zoning Ordinance 1  permit the removal of some trees without replacement. All
trees removed in excess of the standards of the Wadsworth Zoning Ordinance
shall be replaced as provided herein 2 . (Ord. 97-473, 4-1-1997)
 
Notes
1 1. See Title 10 of this Code.
2 2. See subsection
  10-5-3E5 of this Code.
12-4-5: TREE REMOVAL PERMIT REQUIRED:
No person shall commence tree removal, or damage any live protected tree
without first having obtained a tree removal permit from the Village. There
shall be no charge for the permit. Applications for permits may be obtained
from the Village Forester. Prior to the issuance of a permit for tree removal,
the Village Forester shall conduct an on-site inspection to determine whether
or not the removal conforms to the criteria of this Title. The permit shall be
issued if any one of the following conditions is present:
   A.   It is reasonably necessary to remove trees which pose a safety hazard
to pedestrian or vehicular traffic, or threatens to cause disruption of public
service.
   B.   It is reasonably necessary to remove trees which pose a safety hazard
to buildings.
   C.   It is reasonably necessary to remove diseased trees, or trees that have
been weakened by age, storm, fire, or other injury.
   D.   It is reasonably necessary, consistent with sound and recognized
forestry practices, for the tree to be removed.
   E.   It is reasonably necessary to remove the trees in order to construct
proposed improvements, which are consistent with the zoning of the property
upon which the tree is located, and there is no reasonable alternative
available on the site.
   F.   In order to comply with any other applicable Village ordinance
provisions, it is necessary for the trees to be cut or relocated. (Ord. 97-473,
4-1-1997)
12-4-6: EXCEPTIONS:
   A.   Utility Company Exemption: Utility companies, in the maintenance of
their operating and distribution equipment and facilities, are exempt from the
provisions of this Chapter.
   B.   Replacement Exemption: No replacement shall be required if the Village
Forester determines that the tree or trees to be removed are dead or unsafe.
(Ord. 97-473, 4-1-1997)
CHAPTER 5
LANDSCAPE STANDARDS
SECTION:
12-5-1: Scope
12-5-2: Natural Resource Protection Areas
12-5-3: Scenic Corridor Areas
12-5-4: Subdivisions
12-5-5: Site Improvements - Residential
12-5-6: Site Improvements - Nonresidential
12-5-1: SCOPE:
This chapter sets forth the standards for landscaping subdivisions, individual
businesses, and other uses falling within the scope of regulation of this
title. The standards and regulations of this chapter are further divided into
five (5) separate sets of standards and regulations covering the landscaping of
natural resource protection areas, scenic corridor areas, subdivisions, site
improvements, and buffers and required yards; any new subdivision or any
business, industry or other development required to be landscaped which
contains any or all of these features shall be landscaped so that the
requirement for each feature present thereon is met and a unified design is
prepared for the entire subdivision or site. (Ord. 97-473, 4-1-1997)
12-5-2: NATURAL RESOURCE PROTECTION AREAS:
   A.   Natural resource protection areas, as defined and established in titles
10 and 11 of this code, shall be maintained in a manner consistent with the
preservation of the resource. The landscape treatment shall be the minimum
treatment required to repair any damage to the resource incidental to the
development of the lot, to maintain the resource in an unchanged and
nonimpacted condition, and to allow appropriate future open space use of the
resource protection area consistent with the requirement for the protection and
preservation of the resource.
   B.   The area of protection of such resource shall be deleted from the area
of the lot for purposes of determining the landscaping requirements of the
balance of the lot. The owner shall submit to the village as part of the
landscape plan a resource protection plan indicating the landscape treatment of
all required resource protection areas 1 .
   C.   The resource protection measures required by all agencies having
jurisdiction over the site, other than the village, shall be adhered to and
shall form the basis for the resource protection plan for those resources which
fall within the jurisdiction of outside agencies. In particular, any
requirements of the U.S. army corps of engineers regarding wetlands and the
Lake County stormwater management agency regarding detention facilities shall
be complied with. The regulations and approvals of such agencies shall not
limit the village in requiring adequate resource protection as provided in
title 10 of this code and this title. (Ord. 97-473, 4-1-1997)
 
Notes
1 1. See subsections
  10-5-3E and F of this code and chapter 6 of this title.
12-5-3: SCENIC CORRIDOR AREAS:
The scenic corridor overlay district regulations of the Wadsworth zoning
ordinance 1  are intended to help preserve the natural scenic qualities of the
Wadsworth area. Of particular interest are the open fields, wetlands and stands
of hardwood forests. The wetlands and forest are protected natural resource
features under subsection
10-5-3E of this code. The standards for landscaping applicable to scenic
corridors require first the protection of natural resources. Beyond this the
owner has a choice in the preservation and continuation of other natural and
manmade environments such as old fields, farm fields, pastures and commercial
tree plantings of various kinds. Last, there are requirements for the landscape
improvements to be installed in those portions of the scenic corridors which
are clearly deficient in scenic resources of all types.
   A.   Protected Natural Resources: Natural resources required to be protected
under the Wadsworth zoning ordinance 2  shall be protected in scenic corridors.
Even though the Wadsworth zoning ordinance 3  provides that a portion of a
resource may be developed for other use, all parts of the resource lying within
a scenic corridor shall be protected. While some minimal landscape improvements
may be needed to stabilize or better protect the resource, no further
landscaping and no additional tree planting is required. The natural resources
required to be protected are:
      1.   Mature woodlands;
      2.   Young woodlands;
      3.   Wetlands;
      4.   Flood plains;
      5.   Steep slopes;
      6.   Lakes;
      7.   Ponds;
      8.   Lake shorelines;
      9.   Pond shorelines; and
      10.   Drainageways.
   B.   Other Natural Resources:
      1.   Old Fields: Old field environments in which the emergent trees are
at least six feet (6') in height may be preserved as part of a scenic corridor
and no further landscaping is required for such old field areas.
      2.   Farm Fields And Pastures: Farm fields and pastures may be retained
as part of a scenic corridor provided they adjoin or are part of a larger field
or pastures which are continued and maintained as part of the development.
      3.   Commercial Tree Plantings: Commercial plantings may be continued in
scenic corridors. Orchards may be retained as long as they are operated or they
may be abandoned without further landscaping required. Nurseries may be
retained as long as they are operated. Upon the cessation of operation, such
areas shall be landscaped in accordance with the standards of subsection C of
this Section. Other tree farms may be retained. At the time any such tree farm
is harvested, the scenic corridor portion shall be landscaped in accordance
with the following regulations.
   C.   Other Areas: All other areas within the scenic corridor, exclusive of
the protected natural resources and other natural resources, retained as part
of the landscape plan shall be landscaped in accordance with the following
standards:
      1.   Farm fields (field crop areas) which are abandoned along with all
disturbed areas shall be seeded or sodded. Pastures and other old fields which
are not retained as part of the landscape plan as other natural resources may
be left in a natural state, subject to the required tree planting.
      2.   Trees shall be planted within the scenic corridor area exclusive of
any conservation areas as provided in subsections A and B of this Section, in
accordance with the following standards:
Canopy trees (BB - 3 inches)     4/10,000 square feet
Ornamental trees (BB - 2 inches) 2/10,000 square feet
Shrubs (BB - 2 foot height)      5/10,000 square feet
Or
Canopy trees (BB - 3 inches)     1/10,000 square feet
Canopy trees (BR - 1 inch)       8/10,000 square feet
Ornamental trees (BB - 2 inches) 1/10,000 square feet
Ornamental trees (BR - 1 inch)   2/10,000 square feet
Shrubs (CTR - 1 gallon)          20/10,000 square feet
 
      3.   Earth berms may be constructed within the scenic corridor areas
outside any areas reserved for the protection of natural resources. Such berms
shall have fore and back slopes of no greater pitch than three to one (3:1).
Berms shall be seeded or sodded and planted in accordance with the above
standards.
      4.   Scenic corridor areas may be reforested in accordance with the
standards and regulations of Section
10-4-3 of this Code.
   D.   Credit For Existing Trees: Existing trees and trees saved from
orchards, nurseries and other commercial tree plantations may be substituted
for new trees required as replacement trees or for new trees as otherwise
required by this Title. Credit shall be given on a one-to-one (1:1) basis,
provided the existing trees are equal to or greater in size than those required
by ordinance and that the species is suitable for the intended purpose.
   E.   Signs: In addition to the standards and regulations of Section
10-5-8 of this Code, the following regulations shall govern the placement of
signs in all scenic corridors:
      1.   The following signs are permitted in scenic corridor areas:
         a.   A single permanent identification sign for a subdivision or
planned unit development when located at the entrance of the development.
         b.   A single permanent identification sign for a commercial,
industrial or institutional use located on the property containing the scenic
easement.
         c.   Signs required by governmental agencies.
      2.   The areas surrounding signs permitted in scenic corridors for a
distance of twenty feet (20') in all directions shall be landscaped. Such
landscaping shall be designed to blend with the surrounding natural environment
and shall completely screen any exposed foundations or other supporting
structural members of the sign.
   F.   Fencing: Only the following types of fencing are permitted within a
scenic corridor:
      1.   Farm fencing to enclose a farming activity within the scenic
corridor area.
      2.   Open security fencing (woven steel chainlink) when required to
protect a utility installation within the scenic corridor.
      3.   Right-of-way fencing where installed by governmental agencies to
enclose their limited access right of way.
   G.   Prohibitions: No ornamental buildings, structures, recreation
facilities, play equipment, or ornamental devices of any kind may be placed in
a scenic corridor. (Ord. 97-473, 4-1-1997)
 
Notes
1 1. See title 10 of this code.
2 2. See title 10 of this code.
3 3. See title 10 of this code.
12-5-4: SUBDIVISIONS:
All subdivisions which are approved subsequent to the adoption of this Title
shall be landscaped in accordance with the following standards:
   A.   Street Trees:
      1.   Number Of Trees Required: There shall be one street tree planted on
each side of a street for each forty feet (40') of length of the street
measured along the center line of the street. That portion of the center line
(s) lying within the intersection of two (2) streets shall be excluded from the
measurement; however, for cul-de-sacs, the center line shall be extended to the
end of the right of way.
      2.   Size: Street trees shall be at least three inch (3") caliper when
planted.
      3.   Location: Street trees shall be planted within the right of way, on
the right-of-way line or outside the right of way but within ten feet (10') of
the right of way. Trees shall be located so as to not interfere with drainage
facilities or underground utilities. Further, trees shall be located so as to
not impede sight lines at street intersections and driveways. Trees may be
spaced at regular intervals or grouped in naturalistic clusters.
      4.   Types Of Trees: Street trees shall be canopy trees selected from the
list of plant materials in Chapter 7 of this Title. In any subdivision
requiring the planting of at least six (6) but not more than eighteen (18)
trees, at least two (2) varieties shall be selected. In any subdivision
requiring the planting of at least eighteen (18) trees, at least three (3)
varieties shall be selected.
   B.   Other Street Landscaping:
      1.   In addition, any area adjoining the street right of way which is
graded to form a ditch, detention area or other drainage feature shall also be
covered with at least four inches (4") of top soil and either seeded or sodded.
      2.   The unpaved portion, not including the gravel shoulder, of the right
of way shall be covered with at least four inches (4") of top soil and either
seeded or sodded.
      3.   Where a subdivision adjoins an existing street, that portion of the
right of way between the existing pavement and the right-of-way line shall be
landscaped to the same standard as new streets in the subdivision.
   C.   Ornamental Landscaping: The installation of ornamental plantings and
other landscape materials and/or features at the entrance to a subdivision
shall be designed so as to not impede sightlines or obscure the view of
identification signs, traffic signs and street signs. (Ord. 97-473, 4-1-1997)
12-5-5: SITE IMPROVEMENTS - RESIDENTIAL:
Where the proposed development of a site is subject to the review and approval
of the village and includes the following improvements, such improvements shall
be landscaped in accordance with the standards established herein:
   A.   Detention Pond:
      1.   Surrounding Area: The on site areas surrounding a detention pond for
a distance of fifty feet (50') from the normal pool or water level shall be
landscaped.
      2.   Seeding And Sodding: All disturbed areas within the fifty foot (50')
perimeter shall be either seeded, sodded or planted with a suitable year round
ground cover.
      3.   Method Of Measurement: For purposes of determining the plant
material quantities required for landscaping a detention pond, the area shall
be based on the on site area to be landscaped less the area of the pond
measured at normal pool elevation.
      4.   Plant Materials Required: The following plant materials are
required:
         a.   Canopy trees (BB - 3 inches): Two (2) per ten thousand (10,000)
square feet.
         b.   Ornamental trees (BB - 8 foot height): Two (2) per ten thousand
(10,000) square feet.
         c.   Shrubs (BB - 2 foot height): Five (5) per ten thousand (10,000)
square feet.
   B.   Detention Basin (Dry Basin):
      1.   Area To Be Landscaped: The area within the thirty feet (30')
surrounding the maximum high water elevation of the basin and the interior of
the basin itself shall be landscaped.
      2.   Seeding And Sodding: All areas of disturbed earth within the basin
and the thirty foot (30') perimeter shall be either seeded or sodded or planted
with suitable year round ground cover.
      3.   Method Of Measurement: The area to be landscaped shall be the entire
on site area within the thirty foot (30') perimeter surrounding the basin.
      4.   Plant Materials Required: The following plant materials are
required:
         a.   Canopy trees (BB - 3 inches): Two (2) per ten thousand (10,000)
square feet.
         b.   Ornamental trees (BB - 8 foot height): Two (2) per ten thousand
(10,000) square feet.
         c.   Shrubs (BB - 2 foot height): Five (5) per ten thousand (10,000)
square feet.
Note: Plant materials selected for planting within the basin area should be
water tolerant.
   C.   Drainageway:
      1.   Area To Be Landscaped: The area of the drainageway to be landscaped
shall be either the actual area of the drainage easement or an area ten feet
(10') on either side of the centerline of the drainageway whichever is the
greater one.
      2.   Ground Cover: All areas of disturbed earth within the area to be
landscaped shall be either seeded, sodded, planted with suitable year round
ground cover, or improved with a suitable pavement or riprap.
      3.   Method Of Measurement: For purposes of determining the plant
material required, the length of the drainageway shall be measured along the
centerline of the actual draining course.
      4.   Plant Materials Required: The following plant materials are
required:
         a.   Canopy trees (BB - 3 inches): One per one hundred (100) linear
feet.
         b.   Ornamental trees (BB - 8 foot height): One per one hundred (100)
linear feet.
         c.   Shrubs (BB - 2 foot height): Three (3) per one hundred (100)
linear feet.
Note: Trees and shrubs will not be planted in the center of the drainageway.
(Ord. 2009-803, 12-15-2009)
12-5-6: SITE IMPROVEMENTS - NONRESIDENTIAL:
For all new development, redevelopment, or substantial site improvements, and
whenever a building permit is issued for a principal structure, in the
following zoning districts:   PL public land, B business, CR commercial
recreation, OR office and research, LI light industry, LI-1 light industry 1,
and LI-2 light industry 2, the following landscape standards will apply:
   A.   Street Trees:
      1.   Number Of Trees Required: There shall be one street tree planted for
every eighty feet (80') of length of street frontage measured at the street
right of way line.
      2.   Size: Street trees shall be at least three inch (3") caliper when
planted.
      3.   Location: Street trees shall be planted within the right of way, on
the right of way line or outside the right of way but within ten feet (10') of
the right of way. If a permit is required from any highway authority to plant
in the right of way, the owner is responsible for obtaining any permits prior
to planting. Trees shall be located so as to not interfere with drainage
facilities or underground utilities. Further, trees shall be located so as to
not impede sightlines at street intersections and driveways. Trees may be
spaced at regular intervals, grouped in clusters, or staggered based on the
site layout.
      4.   Types Of Trees: Street trees shall be canopy trees selected from the
list of plant materials in chapter 7 of this title. On any parcel requiring the
planting of more than six (6) street trees, no single plant species shall
represent more than forty percent (40%) of the total plantings.
   B.   Parking Lot Trees: For the buildings and uses that require an excess of
fifty (50) parking spaces the parking lots and off street parking areas shall
be landscaped as follows:
      1.   Number Of Trees Required: Off street parking lots shall be
landscaped with not less than one tree and two hundred (200) square feet of
landscape area a minimum of nine feet (9') wide for every thirty two (32)
parking spaces.
      2.   Size: Parking lot trees shall be at least three inch (3") caliper
when planted.
      3.   Location: All trees planted and the required two hundred (200)
square feet of landscape area shall be located within the parking areas at the
end of parking rows and/or be placed to break up the continuous plane of hard
surface parking area. For every thirty two (32) parking spaces in a row there
shall be a tree and two hundred (200) square feet of interior landscape area.
      4.   Types Of Trees: Parking lot trees shall be canopy trees selected
from the list of plant materials in chapter 7 of this title.
      5.   Landscape Area: The required landscape area will be covered with a
living material such as ground cover, shrubs, and turf or a combination
thereof; shredded bark mulch; or a designed bioswale or other best management
practice (BMP). The required landscape area shall not be totally covered with a
paved material, stone, or other impervious material.
   C.   On Site Landscaping: The on site areas for the building and uses that
fall under these requirements shall be landscaped as follows:
      1.   Required Plant Materials: For every ten thousand (10,000) square
feet of lot area exclusive of the building footprint, the following minimum
numbers of plant material are required:
         a.   Deciduous canopy trees/evergreen trees: Three (3).
         b.   Ornamental trees: Two (2).
         c.   Deciduous shrubs/evergreen shrubs: Fifteen (15).
The plant materials required for parking lots (subsection B of this section)
can be included in the calculations for required landscaping; however, the
required street trees (subsection A of this section) and the required buffered
plant materials (subsection D of this section) shall not be included in the
required calculations.
      2.   Size: The required plant materials will be of the minimum size as
listed below:
         a.   Deciduous canopy trees: Three inch (3") caliper.
         b.   Evergreen trees: Six feet (6') in height.
         c.   Ornamental trees: Eight feet (8') in height.
         d.   Deciduous shrubs/evergreen shrubs; upright growing shrubs: Two
feet (2') in height.
         e.   Spreading shrubs: Eighteen inches (18") wide.
      3.   Location: All the required landscaping will be located on the site
at the discretion of the property owner or developer on a plan prepared by an
Illinois registered landscape architect. It is encouraged to have all the
required landscaping in a well prepared plan that provides screening of parking
lots, loading areas, and trash enclosures; provides for and encourages best
management practices (BMPs) for stormwater management; provides interesting
framing and highlights the building architecture; is balanced on the site with
good foundation plantings; provides seasonal interest; and includes a good
design in conjunction with signage and lighting.
   D.   Buffer Yard Plantings: If the side and rear yards of any proposed
development in the zoning districts of this section abut any residential
district they shall be landscaped and fenced so as to form a planted buffer
between the commercial, office, industrial, or public use and any adjoining
residential district.
      1.   Minimum Width Of Buffer Yard: The minimum width of the buffer yard
shall be ten feet (10').
      2.   Fencing: A wood fence a minimum of six feet (6') in height with
ninety five percent (95%) opacity is required along the entire buffer yard
except for the area along the side yard that would be within the front yard
setback or would block views at driveways or intersections. The fencing will be
located on the interior side of the buffer yard with the required landscaping
placed between the fence and the residential use. It is encouraged that the
wood fencing be a style that is attractive and consistent on both sides such as
board on board and shadowbox styles.
      3.   Required Plant Materials: For every one hundred (100) linear feet of
buffer yard area, the following minimum numbers of plant material are required:
         a.   Deciduous canopy trees: Three (3).
         b.   Evergreen trees: Four (4).
         c.   Ornamental trees: Four (4).
         d.   Deciduous shrubs/evergreen shrubs: Twenty (20).
      4.   Size: The required plant materials will be of the minimum sizes as
listed below:
         a.   Deciduous canopy trees: Three inch (3") caliper.
         b.   Evergreen trees: Six feet (6') in height.
         c.   Ornamental trees: Eight feet (8') in height.
         d.   Deciduous shrubs/evergreen shrubs; upright growing shrubs: Two
feet (2') in height.
         e.   Spreading shrubs: Eighteen inches (18") wide.
   E.   Variety And Mix: It is encouraged that a variety of species be used in
the selection of required plant materials with indigenous materials making up a
majority of plant material. However, at a minimum, twenty percent (20%) of the
required plant material will be evergreen trees and shrubs. Care should be
taken that evergreen plant materials be located in areas away from possible
contact with road salt used for winter deicing purposes. It is encouraged that
property owners and developers utilize ground covers, ornamental and native
grasses, wildflowers, perennial and annual flowers to add color and interest to
their sites.
   F.   Nonpaved Areas: All areas of a site or lot not covered with structures,
required parking, loading areas, sidewalks, patios and driveways will be
covered with a living plant material such as turf, ground covers, native
grasses, annual or perennial flowers, or wildflowers. Areas covered in a
nonliving material such as stone, sand, wood chips (except as shredded bark
mulch in planting beds), asphalt, concrete, scrap material, glass, or plastic
will not be permitted unless approved by the village board. (Ord. 2009-803, 12-
15-2009)
CHAPTER 6
LANDSCAPE PLAN
SECTION:
12-6-1: Plan Required
12-6-2: Landscape Architect Shall Prepare
12-6-3: Plan Prepared In Stages
12-6-4: Review And Approval - Procedure For Subdivisions
12-6-5: Review And Approval - Procedure For Planned Unit Developments
12-6-6: Procedure For Site Plan Review
12-6-1: PLAN REQUIRED:
A landscape plan shall be provided by the developer in accordance with the
standards and specifications of this Chapter. The purpose of the landscape plan
is to show in one document all proposals for the protection and/or replacement
of existing trees as required by this Title; the protection of mature and young
woodlands, and other natural resources as required by the Zoning Ordinance 1 ;
and the installation of new landscape materials in accordance with the
subdivision regulations 2 , the Zoning Ordinance and this Title. It is the
further intent of this Chapter that these elements, existing and proposed, be
incorporated into a unified design. (Ord. 97-473, 4-1-1997)
 
Notes
1 1. See Title 10 of this Code.
2 2. See Title 11 of this Code.
12-6-2: LANDSCAPE ARCHITECT SHALL PREPARE:
The landscape plan required by Section
12-6-1 of this Chapter shall be prepared by a landscape architect registered in
the State of Illinois. (Ord. 97-473, 4-1-1997)
12-6-3: PLAN PREPARED IN STAGES:
The landscape plan shall be prepared in stages which correspond to the stages
of approval established for planned unit developments, subdivisions and other
business and industrial uses by the Wadsworth Zoning Ordinance 1 , Subdivision
Control Ordinance 2  and this Title. In all cases the preliminary plan shall
include a survey of existing conditions as specified below. Only in the case of
a planned unit development is a final landscape plan separate from the
construction documents required.
   A.   Survey Of Existing Conditions: This drawing shall be prepared at the
same scale as the tentative plat of subdivision, the preliminary plan of the
planned unit development or the site plan prepared for the site plan review and
shall show the existing conditions on the site including where applicable the
following items:
      1.   A boundary survey of the site.
      2.   A topographic survey of the site with a contour interval not greater
than one foot (1').
      3.   Existing roads, streets, other rights of way and easements on or
adjoining the site.
      4.   Existing development including all buildings, structures, pavements,
wells, septic systems and existing drainage facilities.
      5.   A tree survey including the items listed below. The developer may
show the tree survey on a separate drawing at the same scale as the drawing of
other existing conditions.
         a.   Mature and young woodlands either mapped at the drip line of the
stand with the dominant species identified or individually showing the
location, size (DBH), and species of all trees greater than three inch (3")
DBH.
         b.   Trees grown for commercial purposes either mapped at the
boundaries of the plantation and showing the size and species or individually
showing the location, size (DBH or caliper) and species.
         c.   Other existing trees greater than three inch (3") DBH showing the
location, size (DBH) and species.
      6.   Other natural features of the site including the items listed below
which are, in certain circumstances, required to be protected under the site
capacity regulations of section
10-5-3 of this code.
         a.   Floodplains.
         b.   Wetlands.
         c.   Steep slopes.
         d.   Lakes and ponds.
         e.   Lake shorelines.
         f.   Pond shorelines.
         g.   Drainageways.
         h.   Soil types. (Ord. 97-473, 4-1-1997)
   B.   Preliminary Landscape Plan: The preliminary plan is a plan drawn at the
same scale as the tentative plat of subdivision, preliminary development plan
of a planned unit development or the site plan prepared for site plan review
showing the proposed landscape treatment of the site including the following
items where applicable:
      1.   All of the information shown on the survey of existing conditions
regarding those existing conditions which are to be preserved as part of the
landscape plan.
      2.   The proposed improvements to the site including, where applicable,
streets, sidewalks, pedestrianways or trails, buildings or building pads,
parking lots, driveways, drainage and detention facilities, and septic systems.
      3.   Any protected trees to be removed and any replacement trees to be
provided as required by this title 3 .
      4.   Existing and proposed property lines, right of way lines and
easements.
      5.   A preliminary proposal for the landscape treatment of all public
rights of way, public and private open spaces (parks, playgrounds and common
areas), scenic corridors, drainage and detention facilities, and open space
reserved for resource protection purposes under the regulations of the
Wadsworth zoning ordinance 4 , the subdivision control ordinance 5  and chapter
5 of this title.
      6.   A preliminary proposal for the landscape treatment of the required
landscaping in chapter 5 of this title.
      7.   A preliminary tabulation of all natural resource protection areas
showing the existing resource area, the required protection area and the
protection area provided.
      8.   A preliminary tabulation of tree replacement showing trees removed,
replacement trees required and trees provided.
      9.   A preliminary tabulation of all required landscaping in accordance
with the standards of chapter 5 of this title.
      10.   The preliminary layout required for site plan review purposes may
be combined with and show the other features required for site plan review 6 .
(Ord. 2009-803, 12-15-2009)
   C.   Final Landscape Plan (Planned Unit Development Only): The final
landscape plan shall include, where applicable, the following items:
      1.   An overall layout of the project drawn at the same scale as the
final plat of subdivision or the final development plan of a planned unit
development and showing in final form all of the items listed in subsection B
of this section, approved as part of the preliminary plan.
      2.   A planting plan showing all plant materials to be installed as part
of the development.
      3.   A final tabulation of all resource protection areas showing the area
of the existing resource, the required protection area and the protection area
provided.
      4.   A final tabulation of tree replacement showing the number, size
(dbh) and species of trees removed and the number, size (caliper) and species
of replacement trees.
      5.   A plant list showing the number, size (caliper), type and species of
all new plant materials.
      6.   A statement of the guarantee on all plant materials as required by
chapter 8 of this title.
   D.   Construction Documents: The construction documents shall represent all
landscape improvements required by this title or by other agencies, having
jurisdiction and approved by the plan commission as part of the preliminary and
or final landscape plan. The construction documents shall clearly show the work
to be done by the landscape contractor acting either as a prime contractor or
as a subcontractor to the general contractor. Any required landscape
improvements not a part of the landscape contract shall be identified on the
construction documents as "by others" with the "others" clearly identified. The
construction documents shall include the following:
      1.   An overall layout of the project.
      2.   Planting plan.
      3.   Planting details.
      4.   Other construction plans and details, as required.
      5.   Specifications.
      6.   A detailed cost estimate showing quantities, estimated units,
estimated unit cost and costs for all materials used in the project including
installation. (Ord. 97-473, 4-1-1997)
 
Notes
1 3. See Title 10 of this Code.
2 4. See Title 11 of this Code.
3 1. See chapter 4 of this title.
4 2. See title 10 of this code.
5 3. See title 11 of this code.
6 4. See section
  10-5-4 of this code.
12-6-4: REVIEW AND APPROVAL - PROCEDURE FOR SUBDIVISIONS:
For subdivisions, the landscape plan shall be prepared, reviewed and approved
in two (2) stages as follows:
   A.   Preliminary Approval:
      1.   The preliminary landscape plan shall consist of a survey of existing
conditions, and preliminary landscape plan.
      2.   The preliminary landscape plan shall be submitted to the plan
commission along with the tentative plat of subdivision.
      3.   The plan commission shall review and recommend approval of the
preliminary landscape plan prior to approving the tentative plan.
      4.   The village planner shall submit a written report to the plan
commission based on the review of the landscape plan and an on site inspection
of the site.
   B.   Construction Documents Approval:
      1.   Based on an approved preliminary landscape plan the developer shall
prepare construction documents for the proper installation of all landscape
materials. This plan shall conform to the specifications for construction
documents.
      2.   The construction documents shall be submitted to the plan
commission, village engineer, and the village planner for review prior to the
approval if the final plat of subdivision and the enactment of a subdivision
agreement between developer and the village.
      3.   The estimated cost of all required landscape improvements shall be
used, in part, to determine the amount of the letter of credit or other
guarantee required of the developer.
      4.   The plan commission shall review and recommend approval of the
construction documents prior to approving the final plat of subdivision. (Ord.
97-473, 4-1-1997)
12-6-5: REVIEW AND APPROVAL - PROCEDURE FOR PLANNED UNIT DEVELOPMENTS:
For all planned unit developments, the landscape plan shall be prepared,
reviewed and approved in two (2) stages as follows:
   A.   Preliminary Approval:
      1.   The preliminary landscape plan shall consist of a survey of existing
conditions and a preliminary landscape plan.
      2.   The preliminary landscape plan shall be submitted to the plan
commission along with the preliminary development plan.
      3.   The plan commission shall review the preliminary landscape plan and
recommend approval by the village board. Approval of the preliminary plan may
be conditioned on specified changes, additions or deletions to the preliminary
landscape plan as submitted. The preliminary development plan shall not be
approved until the preliminary landscape plan has been approved.
      4.   The village planner shall submit a written report to the plan
commission based on the review of the landscape plan and an on site inspection
of the site.
   B.   Construction Documents Approval:
      1.   Based on an approved preliminary landscape plan, the developer shall
prepare construction documents for the proper installation of all landscape
materials. This plan shall conform to the specifications for construction
documents.
      2.   The construction documents shall be submitted to the plan
commission, village engineer, and village planner for review prior to the
approval of the final development plan, the final plat of subdivision and the
enactment of a subdivision agreement between the developer and the village.
      3.   The estimated cost of all required landscape improvements shall be
used, in part, to determine the amount of the letter of credit or other
guarantee required of the developer.
      4.   The plan commission shall review and recommend approval of the
construction documents prior to approving the final plat of subdivision. (Ord.
2009-803, 12-15-2009)
12-6-6: PROCEDURE FOR SITE PLAN REVIEW:
The Wadsworth zoning ordinance 1  provides that certain types of developments
shall only be approved following site plan review 2 . The landscape plan for
purposes of site plan review shall be prepared in two (2) stages as follows:
   A.   Preliminary Landscape Plan:
      1.   The preliminary landscape plan shall consist of a survey of existing
conditions and a preliminary landscape plan. The developer may, if he so
chooses, combine the survey of existing conditions and the preliminary layout
with additional information required for site plan review in one document.
      2.   The preliminary landscape plan shall be submitted to the village
engineer, village planner and the plan commission at least thirty (30) days
prior to any public hearing for a conditional use requiring site plan review.
      3.   The plan commission shall review and recommend approval of the
preliminary landscape plan prior to the issuance of a conditional use permit
for any conditional use requiring site plan review and the approved preliminary
landscape plan shall become a part of the conditions of approval of conditional
use.
      4.   For uses requiring site plan review which are not conditional uses,
the plan commission shall recommend approval of the preliminary landscape plan
prior to the application for a building permit and the submission of
construction documents.
   B.   Construction Documents:
      1.   Based on an approved preliminary plan, the developer shall prepare
construction documents for the proper installation of all landscape materials
required by this title or by other governmental agencies having jurisdiction.
The construction documents shall conform to the specifications for construction
documents in this chapter.
      2.   The construction documents shall be submitted to the village
engineer, village planner, and the plan commission and shall be recommended for
approval by all prior to the issuance of a building permit.
      3.   The village planner shall provide a written review of the plans and
documents prior to issuance of a building permit. (Ord. 97-473, 4-1-1997)

  10-5-4 of this code.
CHAPTER 7
PLANT MATERIAL STANDARDS
SECTION:
12-7-1: Plant Materials
12-7-2: Planting Standards
12-7-3: Restricted Trees
12-7-4: Recommended Trees
12-7-5: Recommended Deciduous Shrubs
12-7-6: Recommended Evergreens
12-7-1: PLANT MATERIALS:
   A.   Standards: All plant material shall conform to the standards adopted by
the American Association of Nurserymen and/or the Illinois Department of
Transportation Standard Specifications for Road and Bridge Construction,
current edition.
   B.   Source: All plant materials shall be grown nursery stock and from a
site no further than one subzone from project site except that existing plants
from the project site may be substituted for equal or smaller required new
materials.
   C.   Size And Measurement: All measurements shall conform to the minimum
standards set forth in the current edition of the American Standards For
Nursery Stock as published by the American Association of Nurserymen. (Ord. 97-
473, 4-1-1997)
12-7-2: PLANTING STANDARDS:
   A.   Tree And Shrub Installation: The diameter of the pits for trees shall
be at least twelve inches (12") and for shrubs shall be at least six inches
(6") greater than the diameter of the ball. The depth of the plant pits shall
be the same depth as the ball. All plants shall be planted in a soil mixture
which shall be thoroughly watered and tamped as backfilling progresses.
Planting soil shall be prepared by combining three (3) parts topsoil with one
part peat. This is a general requirement, specific site and soil conditions may
require site-specific treatment including, but not limited to, under drainage,
use of native soil, and tree-spade transplanting. The transplanting of
materials found on the site shall follow good horticultural practice.
   B.   Mulching: Within three (3) days after planting, plants shall be mulched
with a minimum three inches (3") of shredded bark mulch or peat with a shallow
water basin around the planting.
   C.   Wrapping: All deciduous canopy trees will be wrapped with a commercial
tree wrap.
   D.   Pruning: Prune all plant materials to preserve the natural character of
the plant. Pruning shall be limited to the minimum necessary to remove injured
or broken branches and to compensate for the loss of roots during
transplanting, but never to exceed one-third (1/3) of the branching structure.
(Ord. 97-473, 4-1-1997)

The following list of trees will not be allowed to be planted as street trees
in the dedicated rights of way, within ten feet (10') of a right of way or
within sewer and water utility easements where tree roots will damage sewer and
water lines:

CHAPTER 8
MAINTENANCE AND GUARANTEES
SECTION:
12-8-1: Maintenance
12-8-2: Guarantees
12-8-1: MAINTENANCE:
For any subdivision, planned unit development or other development for which
landscaping is required under this Title, the owner or developer is encouraged
to prepare and implement a comprehensive landscape maintenance program. Such
program should include, as a minimum, insect and disease control in conformance
with State of Illinois licensing requirements, pruning, fertilization, weed
control and watering.
   A.   Natural Resource Protection Areas:
      1.   During construction and during the time that the developer continues
to own a lot in a subdivision or planned unit development upon which has been
placed a conservation easement for the purpose of protecting natural resources,
it shall be the developer's responsibility to maintain such conservation
easement and to keep the area free of all buildings, equipment, storage areas
and other incursions and activities that threaten the integrity of the
protected resource.
      2.   Once a lot has been sold and after expiration of the required period
for guarantees, it shall be the responsibility of the owner of property upon
which a conservation easement has been placed for the purpose of protecting
natural resources to maintain such conservation easement and to keep the area
free of all buildings, storage areas, and other incursions and activities that
threaten the integrity of the protected resource.
   B.   Scenic Corridors: It shall be the responsibility of the owner of the
property upon which a scenic corridor is located to ensure that the scenic
corridor is maintained in conformance to the requirements of the Wadsworth
Zoning Ordinance 1  and the approved landscape plan where one exists and to
keep the area free of all buildings, unapproved landscape features, signs and
fences.
   C.   Other Restrictions: Nothing herein shall prevent the establishment and
enforcement by covenant or by the action of the governing body of a homeowners
association of higher standards of maintenance in accordance with the approved
landscape plan. (Ord. 97-473, 4-1-1997)
 
Notes
1 1. See Title 10 of this Code.
12-8-2: GUARANTEES:
   A.   Subdivisions And Planned Unit Developments: Landscape improvements
shall be subject to the same guarantees as other improvements under the
Subdivision Control Ordinance 1 . Such guarantees shall remain the
responsibility of the developer throughout the guarantee period. Further, it
shall be the developer's responsibility to remove and replace dead or diseased
plant materials, including any plant materials which fail to exhibit healthy,
vigorous growth compared to other materials in the vicinity. This
responsibility shall extend throughout the guarantee period.
   B.   Site Development Projects: The owner or developer shall guarantee all
materials for a period of one year from the date of the issuance of an
occupancy permit or other required approval by the Village. In no case shall
the guarantee period be less than one year from the date of the installation of
the plant materials.
   C.   Transplanted Materials: The owner or developer shall guarantee all
materials transplanted from on-site locations for the same period required for
nursery grown materials. (Ord. 97-473, 4-1-1997)
 
Notes
1 1. See Title 11 of this Code.
CHAPTER 9
EXCEPTIONS AND VARIATIONS
SECTION:
12-9-1: Exceptions
12-9-2: Variations
12-9-1: EXCEPTIONS:
Nothing herein shall restrict any public utility in the lawful operation and
maintenance of its distribution and collection facilities including aboveground
and buried wires and cables and piping, transmission or broadcast facilities as
provided by law. (Ord. 97-473, 4-1-1997)
12-9-2: VARIATIONS:
   A.   Standards: The Village Board may vary the terms and regulations of this
Title where it finds:
      1.   The strict enforcement of this Title will cause hardship or
practical difficulty for the owner.
      2.   The granting of the variation will not be detrimental to the public
health, safety or general welfare or injurious to other property or improvement
in the immediate vicinity.
      3.   The variation will be the least deviation from the requirements of
this Title which will mitigate the hardship or practical difficulty which gives
basis to the variation.
      4.   The variation when granted will not also vary the provisions of
either the Wadsworth Subdivision Control Ordinance 1  or the Wadsworth Zoning
Ordinance 2 .
   B.   Procedures: All variation shall be requested in writing and shall be
acted upon by the Village Board. (Ord. 97-473, 4-1-1997)
 
Notes
1 1. See Title 11 of this Code.
2 2. See Title 10 of this Code.
CHAPTER 10
PENALTIES
SECTION:
12-10-1: Fine
12-10-2: Replacement Of Trees
12-10-1: FINE:
Any person who shall violate any of the provisions of this Title shall, upon
conviction, be fined not less than one hundred dollars ($100.00) nor more than
seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00) for each violation. A separate offense
shall be deemed to occur for each day a violation occurs or continues. Further,
a separate offense shall be deemed committed for each tree that is damaged,
removed, cut or otherwise assaulted without a permit. (Ord. 97-473, 4-1-1997)
12-10-2: REPLACEMENT OF TREES:
In addition to the penalty prescribed in Section
12-10-1 of this Chapter, any trees which were damaged or removed in
contravention of this Title shall be replaced with like species in accordance
with the replacement formulas contained herein by the person convicted of
violating this Title. (Ord. 97-473, 4-1-1997)
